Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["DIAGRAM OF TRIANGULATION MARKS OF THE ORDNANCE SURVEY"], "makers": ["Museum"], "organisations/institutions": ["ORDNANCE SURVEY"], "dates": ["1920-388"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["primary (first order) triangulation stations", "marked by means of a gun-metal bolt let into a block of concrete 2-ft. cube", "exact point is indicated by a small hole drilled in the top of the bolt, which is protected by an iron cover", "top of the block is at least two feet below the surface of the ground, except when set in solid rock", "cairn is built over the point when circumstances allow", "secondary triangulation stations are marked in the same way, except that the dimensions of the block, bolt and cover are all less than in the case of the primary stations", "tertiary stations are marked in the same way as permanent traverse stations", "brass bolt, having a cylindrical hole 7/16ths of an inch diameter drilled in its top", "cemented into a 30-in. iron socket, which is rammed into the ground until it is from 9 to 12 in. beneath the ground surface and then filled with concrete"], "other": ["Inv."]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["DIAGRAM OF TRAVERSE MARK OF THE ORDNANCE SURVEY"], "makers": ["Made in the Museum"], "organisations/institutions": ["Ordnance Survey"], "dates": ["1920-386"], "places": ["Egypt", "towns"], "descriptions": ["To provide additional points for the control of the detailed survey, traverse lines are run between third or fourth order triangulation points with a theodolite by which, at each change of direction of the traverse line (traverse point), the azimuth of the forward line is measured.", "All such traverse points in towns are now marked by means of a brass bolt, into the top of which can be fitted the 15-in. observing rod or the foot of the traverse pole.", "For temporary marks the bolts are cemented into the curb of the pavement.", "For permanent marks a 30-in. iron socket, similar to the base of an iron telegraph pole (Figs. 1 and 2) is rammed into the ground till the top is 9 to 12 in. below the surface.", "The socket is filled with cement or concrete, and the bolt cemented in at the top.", "The number of points so marked varies according to the nature of the survey. In some continental cadastral surveys the average number is 20 to 50 per square kilometre in the country, and 100 to 150 in towns. In the highly cultivated land of Egypt where holdings are small but the land is level and unobstructed by hedges, about 16 to 20 per square kilometre are used."], "other": ["Figs. 1 and 2"]}
Unique_to_New: {"object_names": [], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": ["Science Museum Group"], "dates": [], "places": [], "descriptions": [], "other": []}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["TRIANGULATION STATION MARK"], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": ["Geodetic Survey of Canada"], "dates": ["1922"], "places": ["Canada"], "descriptions": ["Stations of the Primary Triangulation of Canada are marked by means of circular metal bolts of the type exhibited, the bolts being embedded in concrete or leaded into rock. Both underground and surface marks are employed, and reference monuments provided to facilitate recovery of the station. The bolt consists of a 3-in. circular bronze disc, attached to a 3-in. cylindrical shank, which is corrugated and fox-wedged so that the shank expands tightly against the sides of the hole drilled to receive it when the bolt is driven in. The centre of the disc has a triangle engraved upon it, with a central hole punched to define the exact station point."], "other": ["Inv. 1922-726"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["DIAGRAM OF BENCH MARKS", "standard bench mark", "embedded type of mark"], "makers": ["Survey of India"], "organisations/institutions": ["Survey of India", "Europe"], "dates": ["1904"], "places": ["India", "Karachi"], "descriptions": ["The type of mark now employed in India varies according to the character of the neighbourhood.", "In towns or cities the standard bench mark is used, as being less liable to interference than the metal bolts employed in Europe.", "In places where there is an outcrop of hard rock, the mark is made on this and suitably protected, as in the centre diagram.", "The embedded type of mark is more suitable in country districts, where no ground-rock or permanent stone building is available.", "It consists of a stone monolith of 2 ft. square section, 3 ft. high, set upon a foundation of concrete 6\u00bd ft. square by 2 ft. deep.", "The top of the monolith is cut in the form of a frustrum of a pyramid, and terminates in a square of 3 in. side, the central point of which constitutes the mark.", "The bench-mark inscribed upon ground-rock is protected by a masonry column, closed at the top by means of a stone slab on which is engraved the inscription \"G.T. Survey, Upper Mark.\"", "The \"embedded\" bench mark consists of a 4-in. iron pipe embedded in well-rammed earth about 2 ft. below the ground level.", "A brickwork arch on concrete abatments is built over this mark in order to distribute the weight of traffic passing near. Above this arch is more rammed earth surrounding a central brickwork well, closed by a stone cover with the usual inscription.", "This type of mark has only recently been introduced, the previous type of \"embedded\" mark being a cubical stone block buried with its upper face slightly below the ground level."], "other": ["Inv. 1920-389"]}
Unique_to_New: {"object_names": ["bench mark diagrams"], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": ["Science Museum Group"], "dates": [], "places": ["United Kingdom"], "descriptions": ["Illustrated diagrams showing different types of bench marks used for surveying.", "Includes details on construction and purpose of various bench marks.", "Reference to the Great Trigonometrical Survey of India, Volume XIX, Chapter IV."], "other": []}

Waterhouse, R.E."], "organisations/institutions": ["R.E."], "dates": ["1921-306"], "places": ["Ado Rock", "Awba Hill stations"], "descriptions": ["These two photographs illustrate the construction of quadripod triangulation beacons at Ado Rock and Awba Hill stations during the survey of Southern Nigeria, 1910\u201312.", "The beacons are formed of tree-trunks and branches built up into a four-sided pyramid, the upper part of which is roofed with brushwood to form a prominent land-mark, and at the same time to protect the surveying instruments when taking bearings from the station.", "A pole carrying at its upper end a white flag is fixed to the top of the beacon to render it more conspicuous.", "The right hand photograph shows the framework of the beacon built up, but the roof not yet added.", "The left hand photograph shows a completed beacon, with a heliograph, theodolite and plane table standing beneath it.", "The ground in the vicinity has been carefully cleared of obstacles to view."], "other": ["photographs"]}

This suggested to him the construction of a heliotrope", "the telescope is mounted on a circle capable of rotation about a horizontal axis, and can itself revolve about the centre of the circle. This circle has no divisions and is only for giving a slow motion to the telescope by means of a screw.", "Through a sleeve on the telescope passes a brass rod carrying a mirror perpendicular to it; the distances of the mirror and the sleeve from the axis of rotation of the telescope being equal.", "In order to send a ray of sunlight in a specified direction, the instrument is set up so that the mark is in the centre of the field when the axis of the telescope is normal to the plane of the mirror.", "If, then, the telescope is directed to the sun and follows it continuously, the mirror will reflect its light on to the mark.", "On account of its somewhat complicated form, this type of heliotrope was very shortly superseded by the adjacent double-mirror type."], "other": ["C. F. Gauss", "S.M. 1935"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": [], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": ["Admiralty", "Science Museum Group"], "dates": ["March, 1820", "1822", "1914-376", "1936"], "places": ["G\u00f6ttingen", "East Prussia"], "descriptions": ["more convenient, simpler, and having a larger reflecting surface than his sextant-heliotrope which it superseded", "it was replaced by Bertram\u2019s heliotrope", "For use the telescope was directed on the triangulation mark, the small central mirror being turned parallel to the axis of the telescope. Then the double-mirror was turned until its axis was at right angles to a plane containing the sun, the instrument and the distant mark. This is facilitated by the disc beside the mirror, upon which its shadow is a fine line only, the mirror is in position. Lastly, the double mirror is rotated until the sun\u2019s image as reflected by the central mirror is seen in the telescope, when the outer mirror reflects the sun\u2019s light on to the distant mark.", "Plate I, Fig. 1, p. 15"], "other": ["C. Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["HELIOGRAPH"], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": ["Admiralty"], "dates": [], "places": [], "descriptions": ["instrument, primarily devised for signalling, can readily be used as a heliotrope at small distances", "sighting arrangement is not suitable for long distances", "circular reflecting mirror of 4 in. diam., pivoted on horizontal bearings in a vertical frame", "mounted rotatably in a vertical sheath projecting from a tripod head and can be clamped in the sheath by opposing screws", "mirror can thus be set in any desired plane and the reflected beam from the sun caused to fall upon a small sliding plate, which forms part of the foresight", "foresight is mounted on a sliding vertical rod at the end of a supporting arm, which is about 2 ft. long, and is pivoted horizontally to a vertical collar surrounding the sheath supporting the mirror", "arm can thus be pointed in the direction of the distant station and the V-foresight accurately aligned by viewing through a central aperture left unsilvered in the back of the reflecting mirror.", "When the supporting arm has moved over to the V to receive the reflected beam, and has an engraved dot accurately corresponding to the tip of the V-foresight.", "When the mirror is turned until the image of the sun falls on the plate, with the shadow caused by the unsilvered central hole of the mirror falling on the dot, the reflected beam is then directed towards the distant station."], "other": ["Inv. 1911-155"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["PEDOMETER"], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": ["Science Museum Group"], "dates": ["Early 18th Century"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["This instrument, for registering the number of paces made by the person carrying it, resembles a watch in size, appearance and general details of construction.", "The \"escapement\" is, however, not actuated by a pendulum or balance wheel, but by a rocking lever and spring pawl which engages in a ratchet wheel.", "The lever is depressed by the forward movement of the wearer's leg, which stretches a connecting cord attached to the split ring at the top of the instrument.", "This disengages the spring pawl momentarily and permits one tooth of the ratchet wheel to slip past its point.", "As the motion of the observer's leg slackens the tension in the cord, a counter spring forces the lever into its former position ready for the next forward movement.", "The ratchet wheel thus moves one tooth at every alternate stride of the wearer, and is connected with the pinion wheel train, dials and pointers which record the steps taken.", "There are four such dials and pointers, for the units, hundreds, thousands and ten thousands respectively, the units dial having 50 graduations and its pointer moving over one division every alternate pace of the observer."], "other": ["Inv. 1916-77"]}
Unique_to_New: {"object_names": ["Surveying pedometer", "pedometer"], "makers": ["Unknown maker"], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1701-1750"], "places": ["European"], "descriptions": ["with silver dial", "cord operated"], "other": ["unsigned"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["PEDOMETER"], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["18th century example", "18th century example"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["similar construction and \u201cescapement\u201d to the preceding one", "The cord which is attached to the observer's leg and actuates the rocking lever, is also exhibited", "it passes over a small pulley wheel mounted in the head of the pedometer", "The main dial in this instrument has its divisions numbered in two sets, and a pointer corresponding to each set", "The outer set records the unit paces, and the inner set the tens", "A second dial and pointer registers the thousands up to twelve", "The units pointer moves over two divisions at a time, as it is only moved at every alternate step of the observer", "Surveying pedometer"], "other": ["Presented by Evan Roberts, Esq.", "(15814) Inv. 1916-82"]}
Unique_to_New: {"object_names": ["Pedometer", "Surveying pedometer"], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1795-1805"], "places": ["Germany", "Berlin, Germany"], "descriptions": ["cord operated", "in iron case with gilded indicator hands"], "other": ["pedometer 1795-1805", "Alt, J."]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": [], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": [], "places": [], "descriptions": ["construction less sensitive than the adjacent one by the same makers.", "The rocking lever is here attached to a pin fitting across the top of the case, and the long hook is mounted upon the same pin, so as to embrace it tightly.", "As the hook is swung by the motion of the person carrying the instrument, the pin rotates and causes the lever to rock.", "A two-pronged spring pawl is fixed to the lever at its upper end and engages the teeth of a ratchet wheel at its lower end.", "As the lever rocks, the pawl causes the ratchet to slip a tooth, and thus turns a pinion wheel mounted on the same axis.", "The pinion gears in the train of wheels which record the paces taken.", "As only alternate paces are recorded, the dials and pointers are arranged accordingly.", "Miles and decimal parts of a mile are registered on three dials, the instrument recording up to 12 miles at intervals of one thousandth of a mile.", "The long hook serves to suspend the pedometer from the fob so that it rests against the thigh, and thus gets the desired swing as the wearer walks."], "other": ["Inv. 1911-182"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["pedometer", "instrument"], "makers": ["Spencer & Perkins"], "organisations/institutions": ["F. G. Ogilvie, Esq., C.B."], "dates": ["Late 18th or early 19th century"], "places": ["London"], "descriptions": ["differs from earlier examples in having a more delicate escapement, actuated by the sudden stoppage in the motion of the wearer\u2019s body at each step.", "The long hook is used to suspend the instrument from the fob of the person carrying it.", "As usual the escapement is effected by the withdrawal of a spring pawl, attached to one end of a rocking lever, from the teeth of a small ratchet wheel.", "In this instrument the teeth are very fine, so that the pawl slips over four teeth at each oscillation.", "The lever is normally kept in the \"down\" position by a fairly strong spring, but the pull of this spring is considerably reduced by slightly raising the long hook projecting from the top.", "The lower end of this hook is fixed to a chain wound round a drum mounted on the same spindle as the rocking lever.", "The hook is raised when the instrument is fitted in its case by inserting a pin in a hole in the lower end of the hook, the ends of the pin resting in brackets on the top of the case. In this position, the rocking lever is just balanced, and is very sensitive to small jerks.", "The instrument has three dials and pointers registering miles, tenths, and thousandths of a mile.", "The pointer of the thousandths dial is connected to the ratchet wheel and so geared that it moves 176 times in one revolution, i.e. in one tenth of a mile.", "The pedometer is mounted separately from its case for exhibiting the movement mechanism."], "other": ["Inv. 1912-200"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["COMBINED PEDOMETER AND WATCH"], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["About 1800"], "places": ["London"], "descriptions": ["consists of a pedometer and a watch mounted in the same case and having a common face, with separate dials and pointers", "The pedometer movement is effected by the tension of a string, which is attached at one end to the wearer\u2019s leg, and at the other to a delicately poised rocking lever controlling by its oscillations the engagement of a spring pawl in a ratchet wheel", "The large pedometer dial is graduated to record every hundred double paces", "there is a smaller one to register every ten double paces", "and a third to record each double pace"], "other": ["Presented by Evan Roberts, Esq.", "Inv. 1916-83"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["PEDOMETER MOVEMENT"], "makers": ["Evan Roberts, Esq."], "organisations/institutions": ["British Patent Specification"], "dates": [], "places": [], "descriptions": ["the movement here exhibited is of the type invented by W. Payne in 1831 and still used in modern pedometers", "The escapement of the recording ratchet wheel is effected by the oscillations of a horizontal anchor-shaped pendulum, whose moment about its pivot is just more than balanced by the pressure of a control spring", "The sudden jerk caused by the stoppage of the downward motion of the wearer\u2019s body at each step is sufficient to make the pendulum oscillate", "A spring pawl, fixed at one end to the pendulum arm, engages at its other end the teeth of the ratchet wheel", "A counter spring pawl, pivoted in the bed of the instrument, opposes the thrust of the former with a force sufficient to damp the rotary movement of the ratchet", "This opposing spring is missing in the instrument shown", "The teeth of the ratchet are very fine, so that as the pendulum moves from the upper stop to the lower, the pawl passes over several teeth, the number depending upon the adjustment of the lower stop, which is threaded in a fixed block", "By this adjustment, the indication of the recording pinion can be varied to correspond roughly to the length of the observer's stride", "The ratchet wheel is geared to a train of pinion wheels which record the distance travelled in miles and furlongs", "There is only one dial and pointer, the former graduated in miles up to twelve, with eight sub-divisions to each mile", "The numbering of the main graduations is like that used in watches"], "other": ["No. 6078", "Inv. 1916-81"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": [], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": ["S.M. (Science Museum)", "L.S. (likely a departmental initial)"], "dates": [], "places": [], "descriptions": ["The Odometer, Waywiser or Perambulator has been employed since the days of the Romans for measuring distances by counting and recording the revolutions of a wheel of known circumference.", "It has a brass wheel of 1.5 ft. circumference geared to a registering mechanism furnished with dials and pointers which record the number of links, poles, chains, furlongs, and miles traversed.", "The bearings for the wheel axle are fixed to metal brackets screwed to the case containing the registering mechanism, which itself is fixed at the lower extremity of a long wooden handle.", "At one end of the axle is a small pinion wheel the teeth of which engage in those of a perpendicular pinion mounted on the lower end of a brass rod, which is pivoted at its lower end in the axle bearing block and kept parallel to the supporting bracket by guides.", "The upper end of this rod is geared to the case containing the registering mechanism. This has two pointers and dials, the outer one divided to read links and having divisions both every ten links and every pole, whilst the inner dial is graduated in miles and half furlongs up to four miles."], "other": ["Inv. 1914-895", "Waywiser (used as a generic description)", "Late 18th century (implied)", "Late 18th century (explicit)"]}
Unique_to_New: {"object_names": [], "makers": ["George Adams", "Adams, George"], "organisations/institutions": ["Fleet Street, London", "City of London", "London", "Greater London", "England", "United Kingdom"], "dates": [], "places": ["Fleet Street, London", "City of London", "London", "Greater London", "England", "United Kingdom"], "descriptions": ["Surveying odometer"], "other": ["Marked in poles, furlongs and miles."]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["PERAMBULATOR"], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": ["Science Museum Group"], "dates": ["beginning of the 19th century"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["improved form of the adjacent Waywiser, made by Adams", "The wheel is much larger, its circumference being half a pole, and it is carefully mounted in its bearings so as to reduce friction and shake.", "The mechanism differs slightly from that in the Waywiser.", "The motion of the rotating axle of the wheel is transmitted to a perpendicular shaft running along the top to the case containing the recording mechanism by a pair of bevel wheels, and from the shaft to the recording mechanism by a worm and worm-wheel.", "One of the bearing forks is hinged at the top to the case containing the recording mechanism.", "The outer dial has a diam. of 7 in. and is graduated in yards and poles, its pointer making one revolution every furlong.", "An inner dial, of 5 in. diam. is graduated in furlongs and miles up to 10 miles and is read by a second index.", "The wheel and mechanism case are made of wood, with metal parts where there is much wear, e.g. the axle and bearings, wheel rim, etc."], "other": ["S.M. 939", "L.S"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["SLEDGE METER"], "makers": ["S. Smith & Son"], "organisations/institutions": ["British Antarctic (Terra Nova) Expedition"], "dates": ["1910\u201313"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["This form of measuring wheel was constructed specially for use on frozen snow surface and ice, and was employed on all journeys made by the above expedition when much reliance had to be placed on dead reckoning.", "The instrument has a trailing wheel of diam. 18 in. made of steel, with an aluminium band on its rim to prevent snow from clinging to the surface and with steel pegs fitted into the rim so as to enable the wheel to roll without slipping on ice surfaces.", "The wheel is mounted in ball bearings upon a metal fork to which the recording mechanism is attached.", "The gearing is completely enclosed and the dial gives reading in geographical miles, subdivided to 25 yd.", "The fork is fixed to a wooden bar to which at the other end is attached a cross-head connected to the bar by a universal joint. This permits the instrument to follow the track of a sledge without partaking of its lateral movements.", "The instrument gave satisfactory readings over soft snow surfaces but registered too low on a very hard surface owing to the steel spikes giving a variable periphery."], "other": ["Inv. 1914-111"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["PHOTOGRAPH OF EARLY EGYPTIAN LAND MEASURERS"], "makers": ["Captain H. G. Lyons, F.R.S."], "organisations/institutions": ["Amon"], "dates": ["Circa 1400 B.C. (Contextual date of depicted scene)", "Circa. 1400 B.C.", "1908"], "places": ["Sheikh Abd el Qurna", "Thebes"], "descriptions": ["Although no map of landed property in ancient Egypt has come down to us, representations of land measurers at work have been made upon tomb walls. This photograph shows the scene depicted upon the walls of the tomb of one Menna at Sheikh Abd el Qurna, in Thebes, a land overseer and inspector of the boundary stones of Amon.", "Two \"chain\" men, or \"rope stretchers,\" are shown measuring a field of corn with a long cord on which are knots or marks at intervals apparently of 4 or 5 cubits; each also carries a spare cord coiled up on his arm.", "Beside them walk three officials carrying writing materials and a bag probably containing documents and plans relating to the property.", "An old man and two boys also accompany the surveyor and a peasant brings a loaf of bread and a bunch of green corn.", "In a similar scene pictured on the walls of a tomb belonging to a certain Amenhotep, also at Sheikh Abd el Qurna, it is possible to see that the measuring cord terminated in a ram's head.", "See \"Cadastral Survey of Egypt,\" p. 30, Lyons, 1908."], "other": ["old"]}

Chesterman & Co."], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1914"], "places": ["Sheffield"], "descriptions": ["A steel band of this type is preferred to a chain by many land surveyors, partly because, length for length, it is lighter and also because it preserves its length much better after the strain of constant usage. Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": [], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": ["Royal Society"], "dates": ["1784", "1787"], "places": ["Hounslow Heath", "Romney Marsh"], "descriptions": ["This chain was first used by General Roy in measuring the Hounslow Heath base in 1784. Although it was only used as a preliminary to more precise measurements with both fir and glass rods, General Roy was so impressed by its accuracy that, in measuring the base of verification on Romney Marsh in 1787, he used the chain only, and discarded the wooden and glass rods.", "The chain has 100 links, each 1 ft. long.", "The joints at every 10 ft. are at right angles to the remainder, which permits the chain to be folded so as to fit into a box about 14 in. by 8 in. by 8 in. for transport.", "Brass plates are attached at the joints to indicate 10 ft. lengths along the chain.", "In the rough measurement of the Hounslow Heath base, the chain appears to have been simply stretched along the ground, but in the measurement at Romney Marsh it was supported on deal coffers, 20 ft. long, resting on carefully aligned posts driven into the ground every 20 ft. along the base. Thus supported, the chain was stretched by a weight of 28 lb., the temperature being measured by thermometers laid in the coffers near the chain."], "other": ["Inv. 1900-156", "General Roy"]}
Unique_to_New: {"object_names": ["100 Link Steel Surveying Chain"], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1784"], "places": ["London"], "descriptions": ["Surveying surveying chains; surveying chains"], "other": ["Ramsden, J. (Jesse), 1735-1800"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["BONING TELESCOPE"], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": ["Royal Society"], "dates": ["1784"], "places": ["Hounslow Heath"], "descriptions": ["In measuring the Hounslow Heath base in 1784, General Roy divided the base into sections of 200 yd. and erected tripods of fixed height for supporting the measuring rods at each division point; these sections were subdivided into segments of 20 ft., corresponding to the lengths of the deal measuring rods used, and intermediate tripods set up at the subdivision points with their platforms adjusted so as to be in the line connecting the platforms of the tripods at each end of the section.", "The telescope here exhibited was used to sight between the two terminal tripods upon boning rods set up at the subdivision points.", "The movable vanes of these rods being adjusted until their index lines lay on the axis of sight of the telescope, the height of the intermediate tripods was thus ascertained.", "rack-focussing objective lens of 1\u00b72 in. aperture and 13 in. focal length", "fixed eyepiece of the Huygens type", "fixed cross-wire diaphragm between the two lenses", "The magnifying power of the eyepiece is small, and the telescope can be focussed down to a few feet."], "other": ["square brass collars shrunk on to its tube near each end to support it upon the platform of the tripod", "Phil. Trans. Roy. Soc., 1785"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": [], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1817\u20131855"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["designed by W. Struve", "used by him in measuring seven bases of the principal triangulation of Russia", "consists of four wrought iron bars enclosed in wooden cases, supported near the ends on trestles", "The chief peculiarity of the bars is the use of spring contact levers.", "The temperature was measured directly by thermometers whose bulbs rested in cavities in the bar.", "Struve estimated the mean probable error of his bases as 1 in 7,250,000.", "Each iron bar is 2 toises (nearly 4 m.) long, and has a square section of 3\u00b74 cm. side.", "It terminates at one end in a small steel cylinder, having a slightly convex outer face.", "To the other end is pivoted a lever with unequal arms. On the lower arm is a polished hemisphere, pushed outwards from the bar by a weak spring. The steel cylinder of the adjacent bar makes contact with this hemisphere, and forces the longer arm of the lever to traverse a vertical graduated scale. Any slight variation in length of the bar is correspondingly magnified by the lever on the scale, and can be accurately measured.", "Two mercury thermometers are placed with their bulbs in recesses in each bar, and serve to measure the temperature directly.", "There is also a spirit level attached to determine the inclination of the bar.", "(See \u201cEncyclop\u00e6dia Britannica,\u201d XI Edition, Article \u201c Geodesy.\u201d)"], "other": ["Inv. 1876-1211", "W. Struve", "Struve"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["COLBY\u2019S COMPENSATION BARS", "compensation microscope"], "makers": ["Major-General Colby, R.E."], "organisations/institutions": ["Ordnance Survey", "Science Museum"], "dates": ["1827-28", "1849", "1876-1201"], "places": ["North of Ireland", "Salisbury Plain", "India", "Lough Foyle"], "descriptions": ["designed by Major-General Colby, R.E., in order to eliminate the errors in measuring bases caused by the impossibility of estimating accurately the temperature of the measuring bars at the time of observation.", "consists in so connecting two bars, one of brass and the other of iron, that two reference marks on metal tongues attached to them remain at an invariable distance apart whatever the temperature.", "Two bases have been measured with this apparatus, one in the North of Ireland in 1827-28, and the other on Salisbury Plain in 1849. Ten bases have been measured with similar apparatus in India.", "two bars, one of brass and the other of iron, each 10 ft. 1.5 in. long, 0.3 in. broad and 1.5 in. deep at a certain temperature, are placed in a deal box, and firmly connected at their centres by two small transverse steel cylinders, nearly in contact. Near each extremity of the double-bar is a metal tongue, 6.2 in. long, which is connected to each bar by pivots so as to permit expansion, but no other movement of the bars. On a silver plug at the extremity of each tongue is engraved a dot\u2014the compensation point. Since the lengths of the tongue between the dot and either bar is proportional to the coefficient of expansion of that bar, no joint expansion of the bars due to temperature changes will affect the position of the dot. Consequently the dots are 10 ft. apart at all temperatures.", "The compound bar is placed in a deal box, and is kept from moving lengthwise by a brass stay fixed firmly to the bottom of the box at the centre and projecting upwards between the two small steel cylinders connecting the bars. A long steel cross-wise level is fixed to the top of the brass bar and read through a glass covered opening in the top of the box. The tongues carrying the compensation points project beyond the box, but are carefully protected.", "In measuring, the boxes are supported at their quarter and three-quarter points on stands which permit lateral and longitudinal motion. The dots on two adjacent bars are brought to the precise distance of 6 in. apart by means of a compensation microscope. This latter is formed by uniting two microscopes by parallel bars of iron and brass in such a manner that the distance between their outer foci remains exactly 6 in., whatever the temperature.", "The whole apparatus consists of six bars and seven microscopes, of which two bars and three microscopes are exhibited.", "The rate of measurement with this apparatus was six bars per hour on the Lough Foyle base."], "other": ["Plate I, Fig. 2, p. 15", "Inv. 1876-1201", "S.M. 261", "Ordnance Survey \u201cReport on Measurement of Lough Foyle Base,\u201d pp. 163, 164."]}
Unique_to_New: {"object_names": [], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": [], "places": [], "descriptions": ["This is a demonstration model of Colby's compensation bar, invented by Major General Colby."], "other": ["SMG 1959-185"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": [], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": [], "places": ["Delimi River", "Narguta"], "descriptions": ["These four photographs of the measurement of the Narguta base in 1912, during the survey of Northern Nigeria, illustrate the general process of using flexible wires, suspended according to J\u00e4derin\u2019s method, and the superiority of such apparatus over rigid rods in difficult country.", "In this case a river, the Delimi, having fairly steep banks, was successfully negotiated without any special preparation of the ground.", "Two of the photographs illustrate the approach to the Delimi and its crossing, a third shows the crossing of a deep irrigation channel, and the fourth shows the completion of a section of the base, the terminal point being marked by a ground pin.", "flexible wires", "J\u00e4derin\u2019s method", "rigid rods", "steep banks"], "other": ["Inv. 1920-655"]}
Unique_to_New: {"object_names": [], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": [], "places": ["Nigeria"], "descriptions": ["This collection of four photographs shows the process of measuring the Narguta base in Northern Nigeria in 1912.", "It illustrates the use of flexible wires, suspended using J\u00e4derin's method, which proved advantageous over rigid rods in challenging terrain.", "The images document the crossing of the Delimi River and an irrigation channel, as well as the completion of a base section."], "other": []}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": [], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": ["Admiralty"], "dates": [], "places": [], "descriptions": ["This instrument was designed by Capt. G. H. Blakey, R.N. for determining the distance of a ship on the assumption that the height of its mast is known, and that the mast is perpendicular to the direction of the ship from the observer.", "It is merely a telescopic sighting tube having a pin-hole aperture and pairs of parallel wires set at known intervals apart near the object end of the tube.", "The distance of these wires from the aperture is given by the graduated scales on the telescopic tube.", "In using the instrument, the mast of the distant ship is viewed and the sighting tube telescoped until the mast lies exactly between a pair of wires.", "On reading the length of the tube, i.e. from aperture to wires, the range of the mast will be in the same ratio to this length as the mast is to the interval between the wires.", "As these last two lengths are known, the range is readily calculated, or can be obtained directly from the tables supplied with the instrument.", "Two mutually perpendicular pairs of parallel wires are fitted in the instrument exhibited, at intervals of one tenth and one twentieth of a foot respectively.", "A table corresponding to the former interval for lengths of masts between 100 and 200 ft., and all possible lengths of sighting tube is printed on the tube and gives the corresponding ranges in yards.", "For the smaller interval, these ranges are of course to be doubled.", "Measurements of distance by this apparatus can only be very approximate owing to the absence of magnification, uncertainty as regards the length of the mast and its inclination to the line of sight, etc."], "other": ["Inv. 1876-1209", "telemeter"]}
Unique_to_New: {"object_names": [], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": [], "places": ["Devonport", "Plymouth", "England", "United Kingdom"], "descriptions": ["Surveying telemeter"], "other": ["telemeter 1825-1835", "Blakey type"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["STUART\u2019S DISTANCE METER"], "makers": ["T. H. Court, Esq."], "organisations/institutions": ["Science Museum Group"], "dates": ["1895 (assumed date for presentation)", "1895 (designer)", "1915-399 (inv. number)"], "places": ["sea"], "descriptions": ["Assuming that the length of a distant ship\u2019s mast is known, its range can be found by this instrument, which was designed in 1895 for use at sea.", "Two images of the mast are seen in the field of the telescope, one formed by light rays traversing a fixed prism of constant angle, and the other by rays traversing a movable prism of varying angle.", "These images are made to approach each other until the lower limit of one is level with the upper limit of the other by sliding the movable prism, when the position of an index attached to this permits the range to be read.", "The movable prism consists of a thin piece of glass, ground concave on both faces, and is attached to a slide worked by a tangent screw.", "It thus forms a prism of varying angle in front of one half of the telescope, the other half being occupied by the fixed constant angle prism.", "Ranges up to 3 miles can be read to the nearest tenth of a mile."], "other": ["British Patent Specification, No. 23834, 1895"]}
Unique_to_New: {"object_names": ["Marine distance meter", "distance meter"], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": [], "places": ["United Kingdom"], "descriptions": ["Stuart (designer)"], "other": ["Surveying distance meter"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": [], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1920-66"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["pocket rangefinder suitable for military reconnaissance", "To determine ranges up to 3,000 m.", "two observations are made with it, one from each end of a 30 m. base, which is set off approximately at right angles to the direction of the object.", "consists of a short metal tube having a pin-hole sight at one end and a rectangular window in one side.", "Opposite this window within the tube are two small plane mirrors inclined at an angle of 45\u00b0 to each other.", "Both mirrors can be rotated slightly.", "The observer views the object A whose range is required directly through the pin-hole sight, and rotates one mirror until he sees, after double reflection, the image of an object B whose direction is nearly perpendicular to A's.", "He measures off the base in the direction of B, and again views A directly. By rotating the second mirror he once more gets a doubly reflected image of B. This latter rotation is effected by turning a milled drum in the eye end of the instrument, and the position of this drum when B is again sighted is a measure of the range of A. The drum is calibrated to give this range immediately.", "A thin cord of the base length is supplied with the instrument."], "other": ["See \u201cFieldwork and Instruments,\u201d 1900, pp. 236-239, by A. T. Walmisley."]}
Unique_to_New: {"object_names": [], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": ["Science Museum Group"], "dates": [], "places": [], "descriptions": ["A device for measuring distances, particularly to distant objects, using a fixed base length and optical principles.", "Based on triangulation principles, it allows for the determination of distances up to 3,000 meters by using a 30-meter base.", "Features a precisely engineered optical system with mirrors and sights for accurate readings."], "other": ["Accession number: 1920-66"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": [], "makers": ["T. H. Court, Esq."], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": [], "places": [], "descriptions": ["This instrument is used to measure ranges in the ordinary manner, by solving a very acute right-angled triangle.", "The angle subtended at the distant point is constant, whilst the base is variable, and is measured by pacing.", "Three reflecting right-angled prisms are mounted by hinged joints near the objective of a small telescope, so that any one of the three can be set to reflect rays axially along the telescope from directions at 90\u00b0, 88\u00b0 51\u2032 15\u2033 and 74\u00b0 53\u2032 15\u2033 respectively.", "The first prism is used to set off the base at right angles to the direction of the distant object.", "The observer paces in the line of the base until, using one of the other two prisms, he again sees the object by reflection.", "For both observations the telescope is directed to view another distant point at right angles to the target, i.e., in the direction of the base.", "The number of paces taken between the two observations, multiplied by a constant depending upon the length of pace and the reflecting angle of the second prism used, gives the required range.", "The constant is determined experimentally."], "other": ["Inv. 1911-151"]}
Unique_to_New: {"object_names": ["Surveying telemeter", "telemeter"], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": ["Science Museum Group"], "dates": [], "places": [], "descriptions": ["Surveying telemeter; telemeter"], "other": []}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["rangefinder", "pocket telemeter"], "makers": ["Tavernier-Gravet"], "organisations/institutions": ["French army", "Science Museum Group"], "dates": ["about 1865", "1865"], "places": ["Paris", "France"], "descriptions": ["This rangefinder was designed by Capt. Gautier, a French artillery officer, about 1865, and has been extensively used in the French army.", "Its main feature is a thin prism mounted in a ring at the object end of the sighting tube.", "By rotating the ring the deviation of rays in the plane of the distant object and the horizontal through the instrument can be varied continuously, and the ring calibrated correspondingly.", "The sighting tube is about 5 in. long by 1\u00b75 in. diam. and has a protecting tube which can be fitted underneath to serve as a hand-grip when observations are being made.", "The sighting tube, in addition to the movable ring containing the prism, has a pair of plane mirrors having their faces inclined to each other at an angle of about 45\u00b0, and so inclined to the optical axis that rays incident through a window in the side of the tube in a direction nearly perpendicular to the axis, are doubly reflected at the mirrors into the line of the axis, and pass through a small telescope at the eye end of the tube.", "In the instrument shown, two such telescopes of different powers are fixed side by side.", "One of the mirrors can be slightly rotated so as to vary the angle of deviation of the reflected rays.", "In using the instrument, the observer sets the range scale on the movable ring at \u201cinfinity\u201d and the index of the movable mirror at the centre.", "He views the distant object by double reflection at the mirrors and looks directly through the tube and prism for a convenient aiming mark.", "If such a mark is not quite co-incident with the image of the distant object, he rotates the mirror until coincidence occurs.", "Then the object and the aiming mark are in directions nearly perpendicular to each other.", "Next he paces out a convenient distance in the direction of the aiming mark and takes a second observation similar to the first, but this time effects the coincidence by means of the movable prism.", "He reads off the scale calibrated on that ring when coincidence is effected and multiplies the distance of his base.", "The result is the range of the distant object.", "The movable ring is really calibrated to record the reciprocal of the angle of deviation caused by the prism, which is the same as the reciprocal of the angle subtended. by the base at the object.", "As this base has been made nearly perpendicular to the direction of the object, the product of its length and the reciprocal of the angle gives the range.", "Thus any convenient base length can be used subject to the condition that it subtends an angle of not more than 3\u00b0 at the distant object.", "(See \u201c Notice sur le T\u00e9l\u00e9m\u00e8tre de Poche,\u201d by A. Gautier, Paris.)"], "other": ["Inv. 1910-126"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["MEKOMETER", "GENERAL SERVICE PATTERN"], "makers": ["T. Cooke and Sons, Ltd."], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": [], "places": ["York"], "descriptions": ["standard rangefinding set", "used by infantry units", "comprises two optical sighting instruments, known as the \u201cRight Angle\u201d and \u201cReading\u201d instruments", "two reels of cord, each 25 yd. long, for setting off the base", "The observer at one end of the base uses the \u201cRight Angle\u201d instrument to make the base line perpendicular to the line joining his position to the distant object, after which the other observer uses his \u201cReading\u201d instrument to measure the angle between the base line and the direction of the object from his position.", "The Right Angle instrument has two fixed vertical mirrors inclined to each other at an angle of 45\u00b0. The observer using this sees the target directly and the vane on the Reading instrument after double reflection at the two mirrors. He adjusts his position, keeping the base line fully extended, until the two images coincide. The Reading instrument differs only in that one of its mirrors can be rotated, and the rotation recorded upon a graduated drum, so that the images of the target (viewed directly) and the vane of the Right Angle instrument (viewed by double reflection on the two mirrors) can be made to coincide. The graduated drum is calibrated to record the range directly."], "other": ["Inv. 1914-293", "(\"Handbook of the Mekometer.\")"]}
Unique_to_New: {"object_names": ["Mekometer"], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": ["Science Museum Group"], "dates": ["1914"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["rangefinder"], "other": ["smg-804227", "Object ID", "Object Type"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": [], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": ["Admiralty", "Barr and Stroud"], "dates": ["1860", "1885 to 1904"], "places": ["East Coast of England"], "descriptions": ["This type of rangefinder was designed by P. Adie in 1860, and was extensively used by the Admiralty until superseded by the Barr and Stroud pattern.", "The rangefinder consists of two systems of lenses and right-angled reflecting prisms mounted in a 3-ft. metal tube of square section.", "Each system forms a \u201cbroken\u201d telescope, the objectives being at each end of the tube, along which the rays, originally perpendicular to it, are deflected by right-angled prisms to the centre, where they are again reflected at right angles into the common central eye-piece.", "In this manner two images of a distant object whose direction is nearly perpendicular to the axis of the tube are obtained, one through each system. These images will be separated laterally by an interval which diminishes continuously as the range increases, but does not become zero until the object is at an infinite distance.", "If the objective lens and two prisms of one system are separately mounted and can be rotated with respect to the other system, the two images may be made to coincide by such a rotation, and the angle of rotation necessary will vary inversely as the range of the object. This angle can be obtained by calculation, or a table of corresponding values. In the instrument exhibited such an arrangement is effected by mounting one object lens and its pair of reflecting prisms in a separate tube within the main tube containing the other set, and pivoted to this so that the rotation can be effected by a screw threaded in the outer tube with its end pressing against the inner. The angle of rotation is measured by a vernier on one tube and a scale nearest second of arc, and the range read off on a table fixed to the outer leather protecting cover."], "other": ["Inv. 1909-139", "(See British Patent, 1860, No. 357; and 1863, No. 608.)"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["BARR AND STROUD INFANTRY RANGEFINDER. (Early Type.)"], "makers": ["Barr & Stroud, Ltd."], "organisations/institutions": ["Barr & Stroud"], "dates": ["1889"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["This instrument was made in 1889, and is one of the first rangefinders constructed by Messrs. Barr & Stroud for use by infantry. It is a single-observation, coincidence instrument, with a fixed base of 80 cm., and measures ranges between 200 and 2,000 yd. with a percentage error directly proportional to the distance. The instrument is optically equivalent to a pair of telescopes having a common central eye-piece and their axes in opposite directions along the base-line, at the ends of which are the two objective lenses. Two pencils of rays diverging from the distant object to each end of the instrument are reflected at right angles by mirrors so as to traverse the objectives and form two images at the centre, where they are again reflected at right angles by a pair of mirrors, one of which is parallel to each end mirror. The two images are thus viewed in the focal plane of the right eyepiece of the instrument, and are separated laterally by a distance inversely proportional to the required range. Between the right objective lens and the central mirrors there is a small angled deflecting prism, which can move along the axis, and in so doing increases or decreases the amount of separation of the two images. In one position of the prism, corresponding to the distance of the object, the two images coincide. A scale attached to the prism moves with it and is graduated so to give the range directly. This scale and its fixed index-line are viewed by the observer\u2019s left eye in a separate eyepiece, which also serves in conjunction with a field lens as a small telescope of large field for picking up the target."], "other": ["Inv. 1914-180", "Lent by Messrs. Barr & Stroud, Ltd."]}

Unique_to_New: {"object_names": ["Optical range-finder", "Barr and Stroud range-finder", "Surveying parallax range-finder; parallax range-finder"], "makers": ["Barr and Stroud"], "organisations/institutions": ["United Kingdom"], "dates": [], "places": ["British", "Glasgow, Glasgow, Scotland", "1900"], "descriptions": ["4ft 6ins base", "used aboard ship on Antarctic Expeditions"], "other": ["Optical", "Surveying"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": [], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1901 (Designed)", "1901"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["Designed this type of rangefinder in 1901, for use by infantry in measuring ranges up to 3,000 yd.", "The power of the eyes to \u201cconverge\u201d to a varying degree upon objects at different distances, and to measure distances by the muscular effort so required, is limited normally to small distances of a few yards.", "Consequently, in this, as in all stereoscopic rangefinders, optical means are employed to bring the image of the object ranged upon within the limit of normal eye convergence.", "The use of an optical base, whose function is to increase the inter-ocular distance from 2\u00b75 in. to 72 in., and a pair of binoculars of magnification 8 diam. enables the radius of stereoscopic vision to be increased 240 times.", "balloon.", "The distance between the two balloon images is varied by a micrometer screw. If the observer combines these balloon images stereoscopically into one, and does the same with the images of the distant object, he can judge the apparent distances of the two images, and turn the screw until these distances coincide. The rotation of the screw thus serves as a measure of the required range, and this can be read off directly on a circular scale, attached to the screw and suitably graduated."], "other": ["Inv. 1920-442."]}
Unique_to_New: {"object_names": [], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": ["Science Museum Group"], "dates": ["20th century"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["A portable stereoscopic rangefinder designed by Professor G. Forbes."], "other": ["FORBES\u2019 STEREOSCOPIC RANGEFINDER.", "Lent by Prof. G. Forbes, F.R.S."]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["tacheometer"], "makers": ["St\u00e4rke & Kammerer"], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["about 1868"], "places": ["Vienna"], "descriptions": ["Made by St\u00e4rke & Kammerer, Vienna.", "To convert a theodolite into a tacheometer for measuring distances, many devices have been proposed which permit the telescope, when directed upon a graduated staff, to be displaced through a constant small angle, whose limits are determined by two mechanical stops.", "The distance so measured on the staff will vary directly as the horizontal distance of the staff from the observing station and inversely as the square of the cosine of the altitude angle.", "As the latter is known, the former can be calculated by using special tables.", "In the tacheometer invented about 1868 by A. Gentilli, the Austrian engineer, a rigid vertical arm can be clamped to the transverse axis of the telescope in any position.", "The lower end of this arm can only move a short distance, being limited by two mechanical stops.", "Consequently the vertical angle through which the telescope can move when clamped to the arm is likewise limited.", "The instrument in other respects is like an ordinary theodolite of the type made by St\u00e4rke about this period.", "It has a 5-in. horizontal circle and a 3.5-in. vertical quadrant, both reading by vernier and reading microscope to 30'' and having the usual clamps and tangent screws.", "The telescope has an objective lens of 12 in. focal length and 1.5 in. aperture.", "The instrument has four levelling screws, two small spirit levels mutually perpendicular on the horizontal circle, and a more sensitive one on the telescope."], "other": ["Inv. 1876-1205", "A. Gentilli"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": [], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": [], "places": [], "descriptions": ["An early example of a theodolite modified to enable distances to be measured with it simultaneously with azimuth and altitude angles is here represented in the \u201cOmnimeter,\u201d invented by C. A. C. Eckhold in 1868. This instrument is used in conjunction with a special tacheometric staff having a fixed interval, usually 10 ft., marked upon it. A microscope, rigidly attached with its axis perpendicular to that of the observing telescope, rotating with this telescope about a common transverse axis, measures upon a scale fixed horizontally upon the upper plate of the theodolite the distance traversed when the observing telescope is rotated from the upper mark to the lower mark of the staff. As this staff is always set up vertically, its horizontal distance from the centre of the instrument is inversely proportional to the distance traversed on the scale. The microscope scale is mounted parallel to the telescope at a distance of exactly 6 in. below the transverse axis. It is 4 in. long and is graduated to read 0\u00b702 in. directly, whilst it can be moved on the plate, parallel to its own length, through a small interval by means of a micrometer screw with a graduated drum, which measures 0\u00b7002 of each division of the scale. In this manner the ultimate graduation of the scale corresponds to 4 \u00d7 10\u207b\u2075 in. so that, if n such divisions are traversed when the theodolite rotates from the upper to the lower mark of the staff, the distance of this staff from the instrument will be 15 \u00d7 10\u00b3 \u00f7 n ft. In other respects the instrument is similar to an ordinary transit repeating theodolite. It has 5-in. vertical and horizontal circles reading by vernier to single minutes. The focal length of the telescope is 11 in., and its aperture 1\u00b725 in. It is fitted with a Ramsden eyepiece. Slow-motion tangent screws are provided for each circle, and the usual spirit-levels on the plate and telescope. A diagonal eyepiece is fitted to the microscope for convenience in taking steep sights.", "early example of a theodolite modified to enable distances to be measured with it simultaneously with azimuth and altitude angles", "used in conjunction with a special tacheometric staff having a fixed interval, usually 10 ft., marked upon it", "microscope, rigidly attached with its axis perpendicular to that of the observing telescope, rotating with this telescope about a common transverse axis, measures upon a scale fixed horizontally upon the upper plate of theodolite the distance traversed when the observing telescope is rotated from the upper mark to the lower mark of the staff", "staff is always set up vertically", "horizontal distance from the centre of the instrument is inversely proportional to the distance traversed on the scale", "microscope scale is mounted parallel to the telescope at a distance of exactly 6 in. below the transverse axis", "scale is 4 in. long and is graduated to read 0\u00b702 in. directly", "micrometer screw with a graduated drum, which measures 0\u00b7002 of each division of the scale", "ultimate graduation of the scale corresponds to 4 \u00d7 10\u207b\u2075 in.", "formula for distance calculation: 15 \u00d7 10\u00b3 \u00f7 n ft.", "similar to an ordinary transit repeating theodolite", "has 5-in. vertical and horizontal circles reading by vernier to single minutes", "telescope has a focal length of 11 in., and its aperture 1\u00b725 in.", "fitted with a Ramsden eyepiece", "slow-motion tangent screws are provided for each circle", "usual spirit-levels on the plate and telescope", "diagonal eyepiece is fitted to the microscope for convenience in taking steep sights"], "other": ["Inv. 1900-90"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["DIRECT-READING TACHEOMETER", "tacheometric theodolite"], "makers": ["Cooke, Troughton & Simms, Ltd."], "organisations/institutions": ["Institution of Civil Engineers of Ireland", "British Patent Specification"], "dates": ["1912", "Jan. 6th 1915", "1925-7"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["Ordinary tacheometers are designed for horizontal sights, and the readings have to be corrected by computation if the sight is inclined, whilst a further calculation is necessary to determine the difference in height between the observed and observing stations.", "Many devices have been introduced in the design of tacheometers with the object of rendering such calculations unnecessary, and enabling the distance and altitude to be read off directly, whether the line of sight is horizontal or inclined.", "The tacheometer illustrated embodies Prof. H. H. Jeffcott\u2019s arrangement for rendering the readings independent of the inclination.", "A similar arrangement of varying diaphragm-interval enables the height also to be obtained by reading the staff-interval intercepted.", "The diaphragm has one fixed and two movable horizontal platinum-iridium pointers, the former for collimation and the latter to limit the intervals for height and distance readings respectively: the distance pointer is on the same side as the collimation pointer, and the height pointer on the opposite side.", "Each movable pointer is fixed on the end of a pivoted lever, of which the other end is pressed against a suitably shaped cam, which is rotated by the movement in inclination of the telescope, so that the distance of either movable pointer from the fixed one is suitably varied to make the interval intercepted upon the distant staff exactly one-hundredth of the range and one-tenth of the height respectively.", "The cams are made to suit elevations and depressions up to 30\u00b0, and are mounted inside a protecting case at one end of the transit axis of the telescope.", "The instrument in other respects resembles the ordinary tacheometric theodolite."], "other": ["Prof. H. H. Jeffcott", "anallatic lens", "inverting eyepiece"]}
Unique_to_New: {"object_names": ["Jeffcott direct-reading tacheometer"], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": ["Science Museum Group"], "dates": ["1912"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["A device that allows distance and altitude to be read directly, regardless of the inclination of the line of sight.", "Features a unique mechanism involving cams and pointers to achieve direct readings."], "other": ["H. Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["ANCIENT EGYPTIAN LEVELS", "levels"], "makers": ["Captain H. G. Lyons, F.R.S."], "organisations/institutions": ["Cairo Museum"], "dates": ["1914-219"], "places": ["Egypt"], "descriptions": ["A-shaped plummet type", "used by builders and engineers of all the early civilizations", "survived in use to the present date without fundamental modification", "Each level consists of a wooden frame in the shape of an isosceles triangle, having its sides equally prolonged beyond the base. Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["EARLY BALANCE LEVEL"], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": ["T. H. Court, Esq.", "S.M."], "dates": ["17th century (Latter half)", "Latter half of that period"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["This is a level of a type much used for rough levelling during the 17th century, and probably dates from the latter half of that period.", "It consists of a heavy tube freely suspended from the top of a wooden case by a thread attached to its centre.", "The tube has a horizontal slit at one end, and a corresponding cross wire at the other; glass windows in the ends of the wooden case permit a free view along the sights.", "The instrument as a whole can be rotated in azimuth upon its stand.", "When not in use, the sighting tube can be fixed by means of two screws passing through the bottom of the wooden case.", "In this instrument, the centre of gravity of the suspended tube is very little, if any, below the line of sight.", "Hence the tube is very sensitive to disturbances, which is a source of trouble.", "Moreover, there is no easy method of adjusting the line of sight to be truly horizontal.", "Owing to these defects, both of which were remedied in the more precise instruments on the \"balance\" principle designed by Huygens, this type of level is not very accurate.", "The body of the tube is made of lead, the ends containing the sights being of brass.", "The wooden case is screwed into the top of a small column, provided with a brass socket at its other end.", "The socket serves to attach the level to its stand, which may be a tripod or simply a \"stick\" stand."], "other": ["Plate II, Fig. 1, p. 38", "Inv. 1913-258", "L.S."]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["DE LISLE'S REFLECTING CLINOMETER"], "makers": ["T. Cooke & Sons, Ltd."], "organisations/institutions": ["R.E."], "dates": ["1921-519"], "places": ["York"], "descriptions": ["Of the many arrangements for converting a Burel reflecting level into a clinometer, the one here represented, devised by General A. De Lisle, R.E., is the most satisfactory. A heavy arc is attached to the lower part of the mirror frame and can be turned into the same plane as the mirror for convenience of carriage, or into a perpendicular frame for measuring angles of elevation or depression. In the latter position the weight of the arc causes the mirror plane to take up an inclination to the vertical, which can be varied by means of a movable radial arm, concentric with the arc and carrying a sliding counterpoise at its extremity. The arc is so graduated on its edge that the position of one edge of the movable arm gives the inclination of the mirror, and, therefore, of the line of sight between the observer's eye and its reflection in the mirror. The arc is graduated to read gradients from zero to 1 in 5."], "other": ["General A. De Lisle"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["SPIRIT LEVEL"], "makers": ["Zimmer Bros."], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": [], "places": ["Stuttgart"], "descriptions": ["This instrument, primarily designed for levelling, can also be employed for measuring angles in any plane, and is likewise provided with stadia lines in the diaphragm of the telescope for measuring distances.", "It is thus a type of cheap, portable, universal instrument, specially adapted for surveys of minor precision.", "The special features which distinguish it from an ordinary small level are the graduated semicircle and the peculiar method of attaching the spirit level to the telescope and the whole instrument to the tripod.", "The lower parallel plate is not attached directly to the tripod head, but to an intermediate knuckle-joint piece, which permits the instrument as a whole to be set with the semicircle in any plane.", "The spirit level can also be attached to the telescope in two places, one serving when the semicircle is horizontal and the other when it is vertical.", "The telescope can rotate on the semicircle, which is graduated to 30 minutes and reads by vernier to 2 minutes, and the semicircle can likewise rotate irrespective of the telescope, thus permitting angles to be \u201crepeated.\u201d", "The parallel plate arrange- ment is of the usual type, with four levelling screws."], "other": ["diameter of the graduated semicircle is 18 cm", "reads by vernier to 2 minutes", "Inv. 1876-1196"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": [], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": ["Dingler\u2019s Polytechnisches Journal"], "dates": ["1859"], "places": ["Cassel"], "descriptions": ["later modification of a level designed and constructed by F. W. Breithaupt in 1845", "minimizing the instrumental adjustments usually necessary as a preliminary to taking levels", "method of weighting the main spirit level and suspending it freely in pin bearings attached to the telescope enables the surveyor to compensate by double readings the errors arising from non-parallelism of the spirit-level axis, telescope axis, and line of sight", "telescope can be rotated in its collars through a complete half-turn, the extreme positions being determined by mechanical stops", "spirit level, whilst revolving with the telescope, does not rotate, but is kept with its engraved scale uppermost", "bubble is always visible against the scale, and its variation during the rotation measures the extent to which the axis of the spirit level is inclined to the axis of rotation of the telescope", "such an inclination, if small, will be automatically rendered ineffective provided two readings of the levelling staff are made with the spirit level \u201ccentred,\u201d one before the telescope is rotated in its collars through 180\u00b0, and the other after", "double reading also corrects for lack of coincidence between the mechanical axis of rotation of the telescope and the line of sight", "mean of the two readings will be the true reading which would be obtained if the three axes of spirit level, telescope rings and vision were mutually parallel", "not necessary to adjust the instrument beforehand for this parallelism", "essential that the spirit level itself should be so adjusted that when its bubble is central, its own axis of rotation reversing the spirit level in its bearings should be horizontal", "can be tested by centring the bubble, and reading the bubble again. Half the difference is removed by the means of the two capstan-headed screws which fix one end of the bubble tube to its case", "to enable the spirit level to be so reversed, one bearing pin can be withdrawn from its supporting bracket", "lower part of the instrument is provided with a circular box level, which serves to set the main axis nearly vertical by means of the footscrews", "no attempt is made to render this axis exactly vertical, as the telescope is always finally levelled by means of the elevating screw", "head of this latter is divided, and serves to measure very accurately small gradients", "diaphragm of the telescope has two horizontal subtense wires in addition to the central levelling wires, so that the instrument can be used to measure distances", "suspension\u201d spirit level of the type here shown was soon superseded in compensating levels by Amsler\u2019s two-sided \u201creversion\u201d level, which is much less liable to be injured by shocks than Breithaupt\u2019s pattern"], "other": ["Inv. 1876-1198", "1859"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["ABNEY LEVEL AND CLINOMETER", "hand-level"], "makers": ["Cary, London"], "organisations/institutions": ["R.E."], "dates": ["about the year 1870"], "places": ["London"], "descriptions": ["In a hand-level it is desirable that the object sighted and the levelling mechanism should be simultaneously visible.", "The combined level and clinometer designed by Capt. Abney, R.E., about the year 1870, utilizes the idea of reflecting the bubble of a spirit level into the line of sight of the sighting tube by means of a diagonal mirror fixed in one half of the latter, the other half being left free for sighting the object.", "This device had been previously used on a sextant.", "In the instrument exhibited, a graduated semicircle is rigidly fixed to the rectangular sighting tube, which has a pin-hole aperture and a diagonal mirror fixed beneath a slit in its upper face, vertically beneath the centre of the arc.", "Through this centre passes an axis, carrying a small transversely mounted spirit level at one extremity and a vernier arm near the other, which terminates in a large milled wheel.", "On rotating this wheel the spirit level is set at any angle to the line of sight, the angle being measured by the position of the vernier on the graduated arc.", "The cover of the spirit level has apertures above and below, the latter permitting an image of the bubble to be seen after reflection on the mirror, whilst the former is used when the clinometer is set on the surface whose gradient is required.", "The arc is graduated in degrees up to 60\u00b0 on both sides of the vertical, and reads by vernier on the movable arm to 10 minutes.", "It also has a scale of gradients to 1 in 1, read by the edge of the vernier.", "The sighting tube is 4 3/8 in. long and the graduated arc has an effective radius of 1 in."], "other": ["Captain H. G. Lyons, F.R.S.", "Capt. Abney, R.E.", "Inv. 1914-220"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["FIELD CLINOMETER (Mark III)"], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": [], "places": [], "descriptions": ["modern Service clinometer for measuring to the nearest minute the angle of elevation of a plane surface.", "The angle is measured to the nearest degree by a rotating arm which traverses a fixed graduated sector attached to the base.", "The arm is slightly curved on its upper and lower surfaces, and carries a sliding spirit level whose position, when the bubble is central with respect to the scale graduated on the arm, gives the number of minutes in the angle.", "There are two flat mutually perpendicular base plates, one painted black and the other red, and the sector of degrees is graduated on both sides, one set numbered in black from o to 44 and the other in red from 50 to 89, for use with the corresponding base.", "The black base is used for angles below 45\u00b0 and the red for those above.", "The radial arm has a radius of 5 in., and is pivoted at the centre of the graduated sector.", "The other end of the arm has a spring clutch, with a toothed face engaging in the teeth on the face of the sector and locking the arm in any desired position.", "The scale of minutes on the arm extends through a complete degree and occupies a length of 2 in.", "The arm is thus curved in a circle of radius about 9.5 ft.", "There are such scales of minutes on the front face and the rear face of the arm, the former numbered with the zero nearest the pivot and the latter in the reverse direction.", "The front scale is used with the black base and the rear scale with the red one."], "other": ["Inv. 1922-42", "J. Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["LEVELLING STAFF"], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": ["Ordnance Survey"], "dates": [], "places": [], "descriptions": ["This is an inextensible wooden staff 10\u00b75 ft. long, having a rectangular section 2 in. wide by 1 in. deep, and is graduated in hundredths of a foot so as to be read through the telescope by the observer himself.", "The face of the staff is sunk slightly below the edges to preserve the graduations from abrasion.", "The graduation marks consist of black horizontal bands 0\u00b701 ft. wide at uniform intervals of 0\u00b701 ft. apart.", "The 0\u00b71-ft. bands stretch right across the staff, the remainder occupying the left portion only, save at the 0\u00b705-ft. points, where there is an additional black mark to the right of the corresponding white band.", "Large black numbers, horizontally set, mark the feet, the tenths being marked by smaller black numbers set vertically.", "A diamond is used instead of the number \u201cfive\u201d on the latter graduations, and a dot is placed near the \u201cnine\u201d to distinguish it from the \u201csix\u201d when the numbers are seen inverted in the field of the telescope.", "inextensible", "wooden", "10\u00b75 ft. long", "rectangular section 2 in. wide by 1 in. deep", "graduated in hundredths of a foot", "read through the telescope", "face of the staff is sunk slightly below the edges"], "other": ["15814", "Inv. 1914-422"]}
Unique_to_New: {"object_names": ["Levelling staff, 1914", "Surveying levelling staff", "levelling staff 1914"], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1914"], "places": [], "descriptions": [], "other": []}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["GRADUATED RULES FOR LEVELLING RODS", "portions of those used in the ordinary Sopwith type of staff"], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": [], "places": [], "descriptions": ["illustrates the method of engraving wooden and invar rules for their levelling rods now adopted by Messrs. Watts.", "The portions to be painted black on the white surface of the rule are first gouged out to a sufficient depth and the black filled in nearly flush with the white surface; the black bands are thus rendered very durable.", "one showing the graduations cut and the strips gouged out, the other the finished rule, with the strips filled in and figured.", "made of invar, for use in a precise levelling rod, and the bands of black at 0.02-ft. intervals are not so wide as in the other type of rod, where they are exactly 0.01 ft. wide.", "In the latter case the lower edges of the bands define the odd hundredths of a foot and the upper edges the even hundredths; in the invar rod, only the upper edges are used, the cross wire of the telescope being made to coincide with this edge in taking a reading."], "other": ["E. R. Watts & Son, Ltd.", "Inv. 1922-446"]}
Unique_to_New: {"object_names": ["levelling staves", "graduated scales for levelling staves", "Surveying levelling staff; levelling staff"], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": [], "places": ["London", "England", "United Kingdom"], "descriptions": ["Three specimens", "c 1920"], "other": []}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["PORTION OF INVAR PRECISE LEVELLING ROD"], "makers": ["E. R. Watts & Son, Ltd."], "organisations/institutions": ["E. R. Watts & Son, Ltd."], "dates": ["1922"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["metal scale for levelling staves have until recently been counterbalanced by the tendency of such scales to expand when heated, and the difficulty of ascertaining their temperature in order to apply the necessary correction", "invention of \u201cinvar\u201d\u2014a nickel-steel alloy of negligible temperature coefficient\u2014has now led to its employment in levelling rods used in precise surveys", "The invar rule is painted white and engraved with black bands at intervals of 0.02 ft., every fifth band extending over the complete width (about 2 cm.) of the rule, and the others over half its width", "The rule is then screwed into a central recess in the face of the wooden rod, which has an I section for strength and lightness, and is shod with a metal shoe terminating in a flat base plate; the bottom of the invar rule is flush with this plate", "The face of the wooden rod is painted white and numbered opposite the marks corresponding to intervals of 0.1 ft. on the invar rule", "The numbers are in black, and are inverted so as to be seen erect in the telescope of the level; a V is used instead of 5 and an N instead of 9", "At the divisions of the rule corresponding to an integral number of feet from the base plate, large red numbers are painted on the wood, and are twice repeated in smaller sized numbers on the opposite side of the face so that the observer has always one of the red numbers in the telescope field", "In estimating the position of the cross wire with respect to the graduated scale of the rod, the nearest 0.02-ft. mark is taken and the remaining interval found either by elevating or depressing the telescope by a fine-motion screw, or by moving an optical device which causes the image of the rod to be raised or lowered in the telescope field. The position of the cross wire is thus readily found to 0.001 ft."], "other": ["Inv. 1922-467"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["MOUNTAIN BAROMETER"], "makers": ["Dollond"], "organisations/institutions": ["F.R.S"], "dates": [], "places": [], "descriptions": ["This resembles the adjacent instrument, made by West, in its general character- istics of compactness and portability, but differs in the arrangement of the cistern.", "This is of the usual flexible base type, but has a supplementary syphon tube, connected to the cistern by a narrow neck, which can be closed by means of a cock.", "When the instrument is being used, the cock is opened, and the mercury allowed to attain a fixed height in the syphon tube.", "This is the zero of the barometer tube scale.", "For transporting the barometer, the mercury is withdrawn from the syphon tube and the cock closed, after which the flexible base of the cistern is de- pressed by means of the adjusting screw until the mercury completely fills the barometer tube.", "The barometer tube is graduated in inches, and read to 0\u00b7002 in. by a vernier attached to the movable index.", "A thermometer with Centigrade and Fahrenheit scales is fixed near the top.", "The window for reading this and the barometer can be closed by means of a rotating brass shutter, and a similar shutter at the bottom of the instrument serves to protect the cistern and syphon tube when required.", "compactness", "portability", "flexible base type", "supplementary syphon tube", "vernier"], "other": ["G.
