Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["MOUNTAIN BAROMETER", "Gay-Lussac syphon-tube mercury barometer"], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["about 1840"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["constructed probably about 1840", "in which both the long and short tubes are closed completely at the end, but a small aperture in the side of the short tube permits the air to enter whilst preventing the mercury escaping, was essentially a portable instrument, and was, therefore, often used for measuring altitudes prior to the invention of the aneroid", "The instrument exhibited is of this type", "The barometer tube is enclosed in a brass case, at the ends of which are cork cushions", "Scales graduated directly to 0\u00b702 in. and read by movable verniers to 0\u00b7001 in. are engraved upon the case opposite the ends of the mercury", "Each vernier has an index which can be set level with the top of the mercury column", "The difference between the two readings then gives the height of the barometer", "A thermometer, with Centigrade and Fahrenheit graduations, is fixed near the centre of the tube", "This instrument is attached by brackets to a wooden stand, and can be set accurately vertical by means of three screws threaded in the lower bracket with their ends pressing against the case of the barometer", "For mountain barometers a tripod stand was usually provided"], "other": ["Inv. 1907-65"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["aneroid barometer", "mercury barometer"], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["about 1890"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["for the use of surveyors in measuring altitudes up to 4,000 ft", "The zero mark of the altitude scale corresponds to a height of 32 in.", "The altitude scale has a diam. of 3\u00b75 in., and is graduated every 10 ft., single feet being estimated", "The movable glass cover carries an index mark, which is set to the last height read, and a small lens for facilitating reading", "The altitude scale is slightly raised on a step so that its inside graduated edge is flush with an aluminium plate fixed to the tip of the hand and provided with a mark", "By this arrangement errors due to parallax are avoided", "The instrument is compensated for temperature variations"], "other": ["Inv. 1893-119"]}

Trans."], "dates": ["1817", "before 1821", "1820"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["a new \"thermometrical barometer\" of the type here exhibited", "essentially a very sensitive \"boiling-point\" thermometer", "whereby the temperature at which water boils may be found to within a thousandth of a degree Fahrenheit, and the altitude of the place determined accordingly", "The bulb of the thermometer is spherical and has a diameter of about an inch. The tube has a length of 30 in. and a very fine bore, so that one degree Fahrenheit corresponds to a movement of the mercury in the tube of 4 in. The cylinder can be detached and partly filled with water, which is then boiled by means of a spirit lamp so that the steam surrounds the bulb of the thermometer. Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": [], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": [], "places": ["mountainous districts"], "descriptions": ["Although not so accurate as a standard barometer, a hypsometer for determining altitudes by means of the boiling point of water is more convenient for rapid surveys in mountainous districts.", "The example shown is of the \u201cpocket\u201d type much used by Alpine travellers.", "Its thermometer is graduated from 180\u00b0 to 215\u00b0 F. by 0\u00b702\u00b0.", "The apparatus consists of a brass water container and steam jacket, in which the thermometer is suspended and which is fixed above a small spirit lamp for boiling the water.", "A brass case surrounds the lamp, which is further screened from wind by means of a black japanned tin box, provided with air holes covered by wire gauze.", "The thermometer is suspended with its bulb inside an inner tube connected to the boiler.", "An outer telescopic tube surrounds this and serves to support the thermometer in addition to forming a steam jacket enclosing the mercury as much as possible.", "The steam escapes by a hole in the top of this outer tube.", "In improved hypsometers it is made to retrace its path downwards and escape at the bottom of the steam jacket.", "With this apparatus altitudes are determined by means of specially prepared tables provided with the instrument, giving the heights above sea level corresponding to a particular temperature at which water boils, and also corrections to be made for latitude, mean temperature of the air, and decrease of gravity with increase of elevation.", "pocket type", "Alpine travellers", "thermometer graduated from 180\u00b0 to 215\u00b0 F. by 0\u00b702\u00b0"], "other": ["Inv. 1893-149"]}

Instituts"], "dates": ["1901"], "places": ["Eichst\u00e4tt, Bavaria", "Germany"], "descriptions": ["DRAWING OF A RESTORATION OF A SMALL GROMA.", "Reconstruction based on find near Eichst\u00e4tt, Bavaria", "Another example of the Roman groma, found near Eichst\u00e4tt, Bavaria, has served as basis for Professor Sch\u00f6ne's reconstruction illustrated in this drawing.", "The groma discovered consisted of an iron \"stella\" mounted upon a \"ferramentum,\" also of iron.", "The ends of the arms of the stella are bent and transfixed by iron bolts, which served to attach a square wooden frame\u2014since perished\u2014to the \"stella,\" and to carry the plumb lines.", "The length of each side of the wooden framework was 35 cm., and the height of the \"ferramentum,\" exclusive of the upper and lower axis pins, is 35\u00b75 cm.", "This instrument was, therefore, a small type of groma, and was probably mounted upon a wooden tripod, as shown in the drawing, so that the \"stella\" was at approximately the height of a man from the ground.", "See Sch\u00f6ne, \"Das Visirinstrument der r\u00f6mischen Feldmesser,\""], "other": ["N/A", "(15814)", "C 4 Inv. 1923-493"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["REPRODUCTION OF A ROMAN GROMA"], "makers": ["Made in the Museum", "Dr. Della Corte"], "organisations/institutions": ["Museum", "Accademia dei Lincei"], "dates": ["1912", "1922"], "places": ["Via Abbonanza at Pompeii"], "descriptions": ["Plate III, Fig. 1, p. 56.", "Made in the Museum During excavations in the Via Abbonanza at Pompeii, in 1912, under the direction of Cav. M. Della Corte, fragments of a Roman groma were discovered. These fragments were sufficiently preserved and complete to enable Dr. Della Corte to reconstruct the original instrument with a certainty not hitherto attained owing to the meagre data available.", "The instrument exhibited has been constructed in accordance with the measurements and drawings supplied by Dr. Della Corte.", "As previously reconstructed, the groma consisted of a cross, composed of two equal perpendicular arms intersecting at their centres, mounted upon a supporting staff (ferramentum), upon which the cross could revolve in azimuth: from the ends of the cross were suspended four plummets, through which sights were taken by the surveyor.", "This reconstruction comprises all the foregoing portions, with the additional modification that the cross is not supported directly upon the staff, but is pivoted upon the outer end of a curved bracket, which is in turn mounted rotatably upon the head of the staff. This arrangement enables the centre of the cross to be set above the mark on a boundary stone, whilst the staff is driven into the ground beside the stone; also, sights could be taken through opposite, not adjacent, plumb lines without interference from the staff.", "The wooden staff, which is nearly 2 metres long, terminates at its lower end in a fluted iron shoe, and is encircled at its upper extremity by a brass collar, along its upper and lower faces by curved brass strips, and terminating at the staff end in a brass collar and at the cross end in a brass pivot upon which the curved bracket is mounted.", "The cross has a brass centre, and four tapered wooden arms, completely enclosed in thin iron sheeting and reinforced at their intersection by brass angle brackets.", "Each plummet resembles its opposite in size and shape but differs from the neighbouring ones. The actual portions discovered included all the metal parts, with a few traces of wood fibres embedded therein. The total height of the instrument is alone considered problematical."], "other": ["M. Della Corte's article \"Groma\"", "Monumenti Antichi, Accademia dei Lincei, Vol. XXVIII, 1922", "Inv. 1923-395", "S.M. 1828"]}

In using the instrument the observer takes off the cap and screws it beneath the base to serve as a handgrip. Looking at the common face of the two prisms, he views objects on his left hand through the lower prism, and those on his right through the upper. Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["OPTICAL OPPOSITE"], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": ["Admiralty"], "dates": [], "places": [], "descriptions": ["By means of this instrument an observer can place himself in the direct line between two objects.", "It consists of two mirrors set in small parallel sighting tubes connected by a longer perpendicular tube.", "The planes of the mirrors are perpendicular and one mirror is partly unsilvered.", "The observer views the front object directly through the unsilvered portion and the rear object by double reflection at the two silvered surfaces.", "When the images coincide, he is in the direct line between the two objects.", "The sighting tubes are closed by glass windows where necessary."], "other": ["Inv. 1876-1208"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["TELESCOPIC PLANE TABLE ALIDADE", "alidade"], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["late 17th century"], "places": ["Ancona"], "descriptions": ["The application of the telescope and vertical arc to the alidade of a plane table took place about the same time as the corresponding addition to the theodolite.", "In this exhibit, made in the late 17th century, a vertical pillar fixed perpendicularly to the alidade carries the vertical semicircle and attached telescope, which can rotate about a horizontal axis in the top of the pillar.", "A vernier fixed to the pillar records the altitude angle of the line of sight.", "The alidade is 2 ft. 4 in. long by 1\u00bd in. wide and has one edge bevelled.", "Over this edge, at the two extremities of the rule, are attached two plain sights, a slit backsight and a vertical wire foresight.", "A few inches in front of the backsight is the vertical pillar carrying the telescope axis.", "By means of its milled edge and a wormwheel, the socket of this pillar can be slightly rotated in azimuth, and carries the telescope with it.", "This serves to adjust the line of sight parallel to the bevelled edge of the rule.", "The semicircle has a diameter of 5 in. and is graduated in degrees up to 50\u00b0 of elevation or depression.", "Its edge is milled and gears with a wormwheel attached to the pillar.", "The telescope rests in semicircular collars fixed to the diameter of the semi-circle, and is kept in place by hinged straps and screws.", "It has a rack-focussing objective lens of \u00be in. aperture and a fixed eyepiece tube containing a compound field lens and eyepiece with a fixed cross wire diaphragm between the two lenses of the eyepiece.", "A spirit level is mounted upon the telescope parallel to its axis.", "The vernier attached to the pillar is slightly adjustable by means of a slide and lever, and reads the vertical arc to 3 minutes."], "other": ["Inv. 1889-21"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": [], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": [], "places": [], "descriptions": ["A type of modern plane table outfit with telescopic alidade, suitable for topographical surveys of a comparatively high degree of precision, is here exhibited.", "Similar outfits have been extensively employed by the topographers of the U.S. Geological Survey.", "The table is 30 in. by 24 in., and is carefully made in sections to preserve its shape.", "Brass screw pins fitting into sockets at the corners and middle of the sides are used for fastening the drawing paper to the table, which is slightly recessed at these points to allow the heads of the pins to be flush with the upper surface of the board and thus permit the alidade to slide freely over the pins.", "The board is connected to the tripod by means of a Johnson quick-levelling socket, which permits it to be easily levelled and rotated in azimuth independently of the tripod.", "Two butterfly nuts control these movements of levelling and rotation, and, when tightened, clamp the table rigidly to the tripod.", "This latter has three split legs, 4 ft. long, attached by bolts to the metal tripod head and terminating in metal shoes.", "Any point on the sketch can be set vertically above the corresponding station point, after the instrument is levelled, by means of the wooden plumbing arm which consists of two pieces so jointed and marked at the joint that, when the upper piece is set flat on the table, with its point over the point on the sketch, and the joint clamped with its two marks coincident, the metal hook at the end of the second arm lies vertically beneath the point.", "The plumb-bob is suspended from this hook and the table moved until it lies over the station point.", "A flat 4-in. square metal plate, upon which are mounted two mutually perpendicular spirit levels and a central compass box with a 3-in. needle and ring divided in degrees, is used for levelling and orienting the table.", "The alidade consists of a flat brass ruler 20 in. long by 4 in. wide, having one edge bevelled and a central pillar projecting vertically from its upper face and supporting the telescope and attached vertical circle, and the fixed vernier for reading this latter.", "The vertical circle has a diameter of 4.5 in., and is divided on silver to half degrees, read by the vernier to single minutes.", "It is fixed with the telescope to the horizontal axis, which can rotate within a socket fixed to the vertical pillar.", "A tangent clamp and slow motion screw is fitted to this axis and connected to the vernier.", "The telescope is of the pattern usually fixed to 5-in. transit theodolites.", "It has a rack-focussing objective lens of 1.2 in. aperture and 8 in. focal length, and a rack-focussing eyepiece magnifying 20 diameters.", "The fixed diaphragm has two horizontal stadia wires as well as the usual cross wires."], "other": ["Inv. 1914-742"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": [], "makers": ["C. F. Casella & Co., Ltd."], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1924"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["In this alidade devised by the Rev. A. J. Potter for use with a plane table, the usual folding sights are replaced by a single right-angled prism which is mounted at one end of the ruler, with its reflecting base vertical and parallel to the edge of the latter. Any distant object can be viewed directly above the prism, whilst an image of the object can be seen through the prism after refraction on each face and reflection on the base. When the two images thus seen are made to coincide, the edge of the ruler must point at the distant object, and the direction line of the latter can be plotted."], "other": ["466"]}
Unique_to_New: {"object_names": [], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": ["Science Museum Group"], "dates": [], "places": [], "descriptions": ["A prismatic alidade, designed by Rev A J Potter, used with a plane table. It incorporates a single right-angled prism instead of folding sights. This prism is mounted vertically at one end of the ruler. Distant objects can be viewed directly over the prism, or as an image seen through the prism after refraction and reflection. When the direct and reflected images are made to coincide, the edge of the ruler points to the distant object, allowing its direction to be plotted."], "other": []}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["PRISMATIC COMPASS", "compass card", "diagonal prism"], "makers": ["Schmalkalder"], "organisations/institutions": ["Science Museum Group"], "dates": ["early part of the 19th century"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["The reflecting mirror used by Captain Kater for viewing the graduated compass ring was superseded in 1812 by the application of Schmalkalder's prismatic eyepiece to the compass.", "By this means the observer can read the bearing and sight the object simultaneously, and can thus dispense with a stand for the instrument.", "For this reason the prismatic compass has come into general use for rapid reconnaissance surveys.", "The example exhibited was constructed by Schmalkalder in the early part of the 19th century.", "is fixed to the magnetic needle.", "is graduated in consecutive half-degrees from 0\u00b0 to 360\u00b0 in a clockwise direction, the N. end of the needle being under the 180\u00b0 mark.", "is attached to the plate which has a slit serving as backsight, and is ground convex on one perpendicular face so as to magnify the image of the graduated card seen by reflection at its inclined face, which is silvered.", "This backsight plate is jointed to the compass box, and can be folded down when the instrument is not in use.", "The foresight consists of a vertical wire fixed in a frame diametrically opposite the back-sight, and similarly jointed to the base so as to fold down when not in use.", "Mirrors and coloured glasses are attached to the sights for taking bearing upon the sun and other celestial objects.", "A lever is provided for lifting the needle from its pivot and locking the compass card when desired, and there is a steadying pin underneath the foresight for damping the oscillations of the card."], "other": ["2\u00bd in. in diameter", "Inv. 1905-155"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["TELESCOPIC PRISMATIC COMPASS"], "makers": ["Schmalcalder"], "organisations/institutions": ["Science Museum Group"], "dates": ["early part of the 19th century"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["combined theodolite and prismatic compass", "telescopic alidade, which carries the prismatic eyepiece and a vernier underneath this, can be rotated about the vertical axis independently of the compass box, the instrument thus acting as a theodolite\u2014or can be rotated together with the compass ring, in which case it fulfills the functions of a prismatic compass.", "compass ring is graduated directly to 20' in a clockwise direction and is read by vernier to single minutes.", "attached to a stand by means of a ball and socket arrangement, and can be levelled independently of the stand by four screws which engage in threads in the socket and press against the vertical axis.", "tangent clamp and slow motion screw for rotating the whole instrument in azimuth, whilst a circular rack and pinion inside the compass box serves to rotate the alidade independently. This is actuated by the screw projecting beneath the compass.", "telescope carries a small spirit level, and is screwed at the eyepiece end to a brass plate hinged to a sliding piece, whilst it rests at the objective end in a Y-piece fixed to another sliding piece. Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["PRISMATIC COMPASS AND CLINOMETER"], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": [], "places": [], "descriptions": ["The quadrant attached to this instrument, which is in other respects similar to the Schmalcalder prismatic compass, enables it to be used for measuring altitudes as well as taking magnetic bearings.", "The quadrant has separate sights and a small spirit level fixed to a movable radial arm.", "A mark engraved on the outer end of this arm registers the altitude upon the graduated arc of the quadrant when the arm is horizontal and the sights are directed upon the distant object.", "The compass ring is 2\u00bd in. in diam. and is fixed to the rotating magnetic needle.", "It is graduated continuously in half-degrees from 0\u00b0 to 360\u00b0.", "As the N. point of the needle is attached at the 180\u00b0 mark of the ring, the correct bearing of the object sighted is read off directly through the prismatic eyepiece attached to the slit back-sight.", "A small spirit level is fixed to the bottom of the case inside and serves to set the compass horizontal.", "The altitude quadrant has a radius of 2 in. and is attached to the wire foresight of the compass.", "It is graduated in degrees from 0\u00b0 to 90\u00b0", "the radius corresponding to the former being parallel to the compass plane, and carrying the supplementary sights, a pin-hole back-sight and a cross-wire foresight, for determining altitudes.", "Mirrors and coloured glasses are attached to the two compass sights for taking bearings on high objects such as the sun.", "Schmalcalder prismatic compass"], "other": ["Inv. 1917-78"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["EARLY CIRCUMFERENTOR"], "makers": ["Lusu\u00e9rg"], "organisations/institutions": ["Duke of Modena"], "dates": [], "places": ["Rome"], "descriptions": ["This example was constructed in 1686, and exhibits many characteristics of that period.", "The alidade plate is square, and can be detached from its support and employed as a protractor.", "On it are engraved three concentric graduated circles, of diameters 8 in., 7 in. and 3 in.", "The outer circle is divided in degrees, with two sets of numberings.", "The central circle is a \" Scala altimetra,\" or tangent scale, for measuring heights, and the inner circle is divided into 32 parts corresponding to the points of the compass.", "The movable alidade carries a 2 1/4-in. compass box, and is pivoted at the centre of the plate.", "At one end is a vernier arc which moves over the outer graduated circle, and reads this to single minutes, the 60 divisions of the vernier extending over 61\u00b0.", "The fixed and movable sights have circular apertures, with vertical slits above their centres, and are carved and ornamentally engraved.", "Two edges of the square plate are parallel to the two fixed sights, which can be folded down upon the plate when not in use.", "The conical socket for attaching the instrument to its stand has a ball and socket joint permitting the alidade plate to be set in any plane, including the vertical.", "It is kept in position by the friction of the joint, there being no clamping screw.", "The compass plate is graduated in degrees, numbered left and right from the N. and S. points from 0\u00b0 to 90\u00b0.", "A compass rose indicating the 32 main points is engraved inside the circle.", "On the back of the alidade plate are engraved a clinometer scale for use of artillery, and the inscription \"Jacobus Lussorg Mutinensis Faciebat Romae A\u00b0 1686\", with the arms and coronet of the Duke of Modena."], "other": ["Inv. 1880-199", "for use of artillery"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["CIRCUMFERENTOR"], "makers": ["J. Howard"], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["Early 18th-century"], "places": ["London"], "descriptions": ["has a 10 1/4-in. graduated circle, reading by vernier to 5'. The vernier is attached at one end of the movable alidade, to which is also fixed the compass ring, which has a 6-in. diam. and is graduated in degrees. The sights on the movable alidade, and those fixed on the large circle are each fitted with both slits and vertical wires, and can be used either as back or fore sights. They are sufficiently high to permit the measurement of angles in the horizontal plane, and the whole instrument is designed for such measurements, and not for determining angles in any plane. The outer circle is graduated in degrees, and reads from 0\u00b0 to 360\u00b0 in a clockwise sense. The fixed sights are attached at the 0\u00b0 and 180\u00b0 points. The compass ring has two sets of graduations, one set reading degrees from 0\u00b0 to 360\u00b0 in a counter-clockwise sense, the other set giving every 10\u00b0 only from 0\u00b0 to 90\u00b0 in each quadrant, the N. and S. points being the zero points. The eight main points of the compass are likewise indicated. The whole instrument fits upon a stand by means of a socket fixed on the back of the large circle."], "other": ["Inv. 1913-257"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["EARLY ALTAZIMUTH THEODOLITE", "altazimuth theodolite"], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": ["S.M."], "dates": ["early 18th-century"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["Among the early 18th-century makers of surveying instruments, Sisson is generally regarded as the most expert, and his design of altazimuth theodolite, of which the instrument exhibited is typical, remained the standard until Ramsden\u2019s time.", "This example has a $4\frac{1}{2}$-in. horizontal circle, graduated in degrees and read by three symmetrically placed verniers to 6'.", "The vertical arc, reading angles up to 70\u00b0 of elevation or depression, has a radius of 2 in. and is similarly graduated and read by a single vernier centrally placed on the horizontal vernier plate.", "Both circles have toothed edges, in which engage pinion wheels, the motion of rotation being effected by turning these pinions.", "The telescope is attached above the vertical arc by screw bearings which permit it to be adjusted to sight horizontally when the vertical arc reads zero.", "A small spirit level fixed above the telescope, and a smaller one rigidly joined to the vertical arc enable this adjustment to be effected.", "The horizontal axis of rotation of the vertical arc and telescope rests on standards projecting from the central plate carrying the three horizontal vernier arms.", "To one of these is attached a clamp and screw which regulates the friction between the movable vernier plate and the fixed horizontal circle.", "In another vernier arm is fixed the axis of rotation of the pinion wheel which engages in the teeth of the horizontal circle.", "Beneath the horizontal circle is screwed a compass box of 4 in. diameter.", "The compass ring is not graduated, but has index marks beneath the o\u00b0 and the 180\u00b0 graduations of the horizontal circle. This enables the instrument to be oriented.", "The conical socket for attaching the theodolite to a staff, or to a levelling device consisting of two parallel plates and four levelling screws, is fixed beneath the compass box.", "The telescope has a fixed objective of $\frac{3}{4}$-in. aperture, and a sliding Huygens ocular, with a simple fixed cross-wire diaphragm."], "other": ["Lent by T. H. Court, Esq.", "Inv. 1921-588", "4 1/2-in.", "early 18th-century"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": [], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": ["Science Museum Group"], "dates": ["about 1770"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["In this theodolite, made probably about 1770, the alidade is replaced by a circular plate carrying two widely separated standards upon which is mounted the horizontal axis of rotation.", "The vertical semicircle is fixed to this axis, whilst the vernier is fixed on the circular plate.", "The telescope rests in jointed rings attached above the semicircle.", "The 7-in. horizontal circle is graduated in degrees, and read by a vernier scale on the alidade plate to 5'.", "The vertical semicircle is of the same diam. and is graduated in degrees on one side, with scales of feet and links on the other.", "It is also read by vernier to 5', and can measure angles up to 60\u00b0 on either side of the vertical.", "The compass fixed on the alidade plate has a diam. of 3 in. and is graduated in degrees.", "The telescope, of 7-in. focal length and 0.5-in. aperture, has a single-lens, draw-focussing eyepiece.", "A spirit level is fixed by adjustable screws beneath the telescope tube, parallel to its axis.", "The horizontal circle is attached by a clamping screw to the upper of two parallel plates, which are connected to each other by four levelling screws and a spherical joint."], "other": ["Lent by T. Harris"], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["middle of the 19th century"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["retains most of the features characterising the Ramsden type of theodolite", "Tangent clamps and slow-motion screws replace the Ramsden rack and pinion movements for both horizontal and vertical circles", "small reading microscopes are provided near the verniers", "The supporting standards for the horizontal axis of rotation are not mounted upon an adjustable stage, as in Ramsden\u2019s instruments, but are fixed directly to the alidade plate", "The horizontal circle has a diameter of 6 in.", "the vertical semicircle one of 5 in.", "Both are graduated in half-degrees and read by vernier to 1'", "The telescope is mounted in Ys attached to the vertical arc", "It has a 9-in. achromatic objective", "with a 1-in. aperture", "and a rack-focussing arrangement", "The eyepiece is erecting, with four lenses", "and a draw-focussing mechanism", "The diaphragm has one vertical and one horizontal wire", "A sensitive longitudinal spirit level is fixed in adjustable bearings beneath the telescope", "On the alidade there are two smaller levels at right angles to each other", "and a 3-in. compass graduated in degrees", "The parallel plates are of the usual Ramsden type, with four levelling screws"], "other": ["Inv. 1872-80"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["ALTAZIMUTH THEODOLITE"], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": ["Science Museum Group"], "dates": [], "places": ["London"], "descriptions": ["differs in many respects from the more usual Y-theodolite of the period", "telescope is rigidly attached to the horizontal axis of rotation", "horizontal axis of rotation, which carries the vertical arc", "rests in bearings upon two standards fixed to the rim of a case whose bottom forms the alidade", "case is closed at the top by a glass cover", "horizontal circle and compass are enclosed", "Reading microscopes with prism reflectors are attached to the case for reading the verniers of the horizontal circle", "Tangent clamps and slow-motion screws are fitted to both circles", "upper part of the instrument is suspended in a gimbal mounting within a hollow cylinder screwed upon the tripod plate", "can be levelled independently of the tripod by two screws threaded into the cylinder, with diametrically opposite springs", "screws press against a square nut fixed to the lower end of the axial cone which carries the horizontal circle", "horizontal circle is graduated to 20' and read by vernier to 30''", "vertical arc is similarly graduated and read by vernier", "vertical arc has a range of 50\u00b0 on either side of the zero mark", "telescope is achromatic", "telescope has a 1-in. aperture", "telescope has a 8-in. focal length", "objective is focussed by a rack and pinion mechanism", "eyepiece is a simple Ramsden inverting draw-focussing one", "diaphragm has one vertical and one horizontal wire", "A diagonal reflecting mirror can be attached in front of the objective for taking steep sights", "There is one longitudinal adjustable spirit level attached beneath the telescope", "a parallel one fixed to the standards", "no transverse level", "alidade carries a 3-in. compass", "compass is graduated in degrees", "Surveying theodolite"], "other": ["Inv. 1914-894"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": [], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": ["British and Indian Survey departments", "Ordnance Survey"], "dates": [], "places": [], "descriptions": ["Everest pattern theodolite, although not possessing the advantage of a transit instrument, has been much used by the British and Indian Survey departments since its inception, due to Sir George (then Captain) Everest, about the year 1835.", "late 19th-century 5-in. model", "horizontal circle and vertical arcs being graduated to 20' and read by two opposing verniers to 30''", "two opposing vertical arcs are used instead of a complete vertical circle", "horizontal axis to which the telescope and arcs are fixed, is mounted upon two short standards projecting from a central pillar, supported on the horizontal vernier plate.", "vernier bracket and attached spirit level are mounted on the axis, and are clamped to one standard by opposing screws.", "two perpendicular spirit levels are likewise mounted on the horizontal vernier plate.", "horizontal circle has a bevelled graduated edge and a separate mounting on the vertical axis cone.", "vernier plate and circle have independent motions, controlled by clamps and tangent screws, for repeating azimuth angles.", "All verniers are provided with reading microscopes.", "instrument has a tribrach mounting, the feet of the three levelling screws resting in grooves in a trivet plate and being locked therein by a spring-controlled locking plate\u2014also a feature of the original Everest design.", "telescope has a rack-focussing objective of 1\u00b72-in. aperture and 9-in. focal length, and a slide-focussing Ramsden eyepiece.", "Owing to the low standards, angles of elevation beyond 30\u00b0 and of depression beyond 45\u00b0 cannot be measured, as the telescope then fouls the horizontal plates.", "vertical arcs consequently only extend about 50\u00b0 on each side of the horizontal zeros."], "other": ["ALTAZIMUTH THEODOLITE", "Inv. 1895-49"]}
Unique_to_New: {"object_names": [], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": [], "places": ["York, England", "United Kingdom"], "descriptions": ["Surveying theodolite"], "other": ["with case"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": [], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": [], "places": [], "descriptions": ["The introduction of the transit principle into medium and small-sized theodolites in England took place in the early part of the 19th century. This exhibit is an early example of such a theodolite.", "Below the horizontal circle it resembles Ramsden's Y-theodolite, but the upper part has standards sufficiently high to permit the telescope to transit at either end.", "Both horizontal and vertical circles are 6 in. diam., divided on silver to 10\u2032 and read by opposing verniers to 10\u2033.", "The vernier plate and horizontal circle have independent axes of rotation for repeating angles, and are bevelled at the graduations to facilitate reading.", "Reading microscopes are provided for both circles, and also tangent clamps and slow-motion screws, as well as a similar clamp and screw connecting the vernier plate to the horizontal circle.", "The axis of this circle rests in a conical socket attached to the upper of two parallel levelling plates, connected by four screws and a ball and socket joint.", "The vernier plate carries a single spirit level, parallel to the transit axis, and a central circular compass box, with a 3\u00bd-in. stepped ring graduated in degrees.", "The needle, of rectangular section with its longer side vertical, is provided with a lifting lever for clamping it.", "The vertical circle is attached to the telescope and transit axis, and is read by horizontal verniers on a standard.", "This bracket carries the clamp and tangent screw.", "The other standard carries a spirit level perpendicular to the transit axis.", "The telescope, fixed in the centre of the transit axis, has a rack-focussing objective of 1\u22c55-in. aperture and 10-in. focal length, a fixed diaphragm having one vertical and three equidistant horizontal wires, and a slide-focussing Ramsden eyepiece.", "A sensitive spirit level is mounted parallel to the axis of the telescope."], "other": ["Inv. 1909-137"]}
Unique_to_New: {"object_names": [], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": ["Science Museum Group"], "dates": [], "places": ["Fleet Street, London, England", "Fleet Street, City of London, London, England, United Kingdom"], "descriptions": ["Surveying transit theodolite"], "other": ["6-inch"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": [], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["Early part of the 19th century"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["8\u00bd-in. horizontal and the 7\u00bc-in. vertical circles are graduated every 10\u2032 and read by vernier to 10\u2033.", "The vertical circle and telescope are rigidly joined to the transit axis and rotate with it, the verniers being fixed to one standard.", "The horizontal circle and vernier plate can rotate independently about the vertical axis, for repeating azimuth angles.", "The three footscrews for levelling the instrument are fixed to the base circle of a framed stand having a central conical socket, into which fits the hollow conical axis attached beneath the horizontal circle.", "The axis of the vernier plate fits within this and is kept in position by a screw and washer fitted in its lower end and abutting against the socket in the stand.", "The vernier plate carries three symmetrically placed vernier arms, with reading microscopes suspended above their verniers, and is provided with a sensitive spirit level, with its axis perpendicular to the transit axis.", "The standards supporting the transit axis project from the vernier plate, and have Y-s at their upper ends, one of which is adjustable.", "The axis is kept in position in these Y-s by metal straps; it is hollow, and permits the telescope to be illuminated by means of a lamp supported by a bracket fixed to one standard.", "The vernier bracket for reading the vertical circle carries a spirit level parallel to its two vernier arms, for setting their zeros.", "It has a projecting piece which fits between screws fixed to the standard, and keeps the verniers stationary when the telescope and circle rotate.", "The telescope has a fixed objective of 11-in. focal length and 1\u22c58-in. clear aperture, and a central mirror for illuminating the axis at night.", "The eyepiece tube can be focussed by a rack and pinion mechanism, and carries the diaphragm, having five vertical and one horizontal threads, and the inverting, draw-focussing eye-piece, which fits in a slide permitting a slight lateral motion of the eyepiece.", "Clamps and tangent screws for fine motion are fitted to both circles and the horizontal vernier plate.", "Surveying"], "other": ["Inv. 1876-1206", "Thos. Jones"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["TRANSIT THEODOLITE", "transit theodolite"], "makers": ["Henry Barrow & Co."], "organisations/institutions": ["Admiralty"], "dates": ["middle of the 19th century", "1911-158"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["6-in. vertical and horizontal circles, very finely graduated on silver to 10\u2032 of arc, and reading by vernier and microscopes to 10\u2033.", "In general construction, it resembles rather a Borda repeating circle than an English theodolite, the whole upper part being supported by a single central pillar, so that the telescope is slightly eccentric and needs a counterpoise.", "Both the vertical and horizontal circles can rotate independently of their verniers, so that angles can be \u201crepeated\u201d on both circles.", "itself be clamped to the vertical axis by a tangent screw.", "There are two verniers, with reading microscopes, rigidly attached to the telescope,", "Upon the same axis, but capable of independent rotation, are the vertical circle and a counterpoise circle; the axis also carries a spirit level fixed horizontally on adjustable bearings.", "The vertical circle is clamped by a screw attached to the counterpoise, a slow-motion screw being provided.", "A similar clamp and screw connect the vertical circle and the vernier bracket.", "The telescope has a rack-focussing objective of aperture 1.1 in. and focal length 9.5 in.", "The diaphragm is fixed in the telescope tube and has two wires forming an acute angled cross instead of the usual vertical wire, together with a single horizontal wire.", "Three eyepieces are provided, all inverting: one is diagonal for taking steep sights, whilst the other two have different magnifications.", "The instrument has a tribrach mounting, with three footscrews set in a locking plate of the Everest pattern.", "The telescope transits at the objective end.", "A supplementary telescope is provided and can be fixed near the edge of the horizontal circle. It is of equal dimensions with the main telescope, and is used for keeping the back station in view, and also as a test of the fixity of the horizontal circle when the upper part is rotated."], "other": ["Inv. 1911-158"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["TRANSIT THEODOLITE"], "makers": ["Dennert & Pape"], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["about 1875"], "places": ["Altona"], "descriptions": ["The horizontal circle and vernier plate in this instrument, which was constructed about 1875, have independent motions about the vertical axis, for repeating azimuth angles.", "Clamps and tangent screws are provided for both circles, and for the vertical circle.", "The horizontal and vertical circles have diameters 21 and 13 cm. respectively, are both covered, divided to 10' and read by opposing verniers and reading microscopes to 10\".", "The telescope is mounted centrally on the horizontal axis, and can transit at either end.", "It has a fixed objective of aperture 3.5 cm. and focal length 25 cm., and a rack-focussing eyepiece tube, carrying a fixed cross-wire diaphragm and a screw-focussing inverting eyepiece.", "A sensitive spirit level is mounted in adjustable bearings longitudinally above the telescope, and another is fixed at right angles to this on the vernier plate, between the standards.", "The vertical circle is fixed to the telescope and transit axis, the vernier plate being fixed to one standard, and an axis clamp and tangent screw to the other.", "The trunnions on both standards are adjustable vertically.", "The instrument has a tribrach mounting, with three footscrews for levelling.", "These screws have flat ball and socket jointed footplates which rest on the tripod head.", "The attachment for fixing the theodolite to the tripod is the central screw and spring usual in German instruments, which permits a lateral adjustment of the theodolite over the station point without moving the tripod."], "other": ["Inv. 1876-1194", "horizontal circle", "vernier plate", "vertical axis", "vertical circle", "horizontal", "vertical"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["TRANSIT THEODOLITE"], "makers": ["J. Wanschaff"], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["about 1875"], "places": ["Berlin"], "descriptions": ["constructed about 1875", "has the telescope and vertical circle fixed at opposite extremities of the horizontal axis, outside the bearings.", "This arrangement reduces the height of the instrument and permits the telescope to transit completely, but has the disadvantage that the telescope is not centred above the station point.", "The horizontal circle has a diameter of 16 cm., is divided to 10' and read by opposing verniers and reading microscopes to 10\".", "It is covered by a metal plate attached above the vernier plate, and fits fairly tightly on the vertical axis, but can be rotated independently for taking readings of an azimuth angle at various parts of the limb.", "The vernier plate has an axis clamp and tangent screw, and carries a central socket in which the vertical axis rotates.", "A horizontal bracket fixed across the top of this socket carries the bearings for the transit axis.", "Both bearings can be adjusted on the bracket, and tested for horizontality by a sensitive striding level.", "The transit axis has a clamp and slow-motion screw to fix it to the vertical socket.", "The vertical circle has a diameter of 10\u00b75 cm., is divided to 20' and reads by opposing verniers fixed to the axis bracket and magnifying lenses to 1'.", "The telescope has a fixed objective of 2\u00b75-cm. aperture and 22-cm. focal length, and a rack-focussing eyepiece tube carrying a fixed cross-wire diaphragm and a slide-focussing inverting eyepiece.", "The instrument is mounted on a tribrach, with three footscrews.", "telescope", "vertical circle", "horizontal axis", "bearings", "horizontal circle", "vernier plate", "vertical axis", "transit axis", "vertical circle", "telescope", "objective", "eyepiece tube", "diaphragm", "eyepiece", "tribrach"], "other": ["Inv. 1876-1195"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": [], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": ["Admiralty"], "dates": [], "places": [], "descriptions": ["7-in. vertical and horizontal circles, graduated every 10' and reading by two opposing verniers and reading microscopes to 10\"", "All adjustable screws and parts are covered with wash leather to protect the operator's fingers from frost.", "The horizontal and alidade circles are enclosed in a metal case, the verniers being covered by hinged plates.", "Clamps and tangent screws are fitted to both circles, and to the vertical circle, which is not covered, and is fixed to the transit axis.", "The vertical vernier bracket is clamped to a lug on one standard by opposing screws, and carries a sensitive spirit level perpendicular to the transit axis.", "The transit axis rests in Y-bearings on the standards, one trunnion being adjustable vertically, and is kept in position by metal retaining straps; it is hollow and has a lens at one end for illuminating the telescope axis.", "The telescope is rigidly fixed to this axis and transits at the eyepiece end only.", "It has an objective of 11-in. focal length and 1\u00b75-in. aperture, focussed by a rack and pinion mechanism controlled from the eyepiece end.", "The diaphragm has one vertical and one horizontal thread, both adjustable laterally.", "Three slide focussing eyepieces are provided, one inverting, one diagonal, and one erecting.", "There is a central reflector in the telescope for illuminating its axis by light coming through the transit axis from a lamp fixed to one standard.", "A striding level is provided for testing the transit axis.", "The vernier cover plate carries a spirit level, with its axis parallel to the transit axis, whilst a perpendicular level is fixed to one standard.", "A central compass with a 4-in. ring graduated in degrees is attached to the vernier plate.", "The instrument has a tribrach mounting with three levelling footscrews, whose points rest in a trivet plate; Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["COMBINED THEODOLITE AND CROSS HEAD"], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": [], "places": ["French"], "descriptions": ["hollow brass cylinder of 13 cm. diam., divided into two parts independently movable about the common vertical axis, instead of the horizontal and vernier plates of an ordinary theodolite.", "bearings between these standards and is used for setting the axis of the cylinder vertical.", "The curved face of this half is pierced by two pairs of vertical sighting slits at opposite ends of perpendicular diameters, and the lower circular edge, which is in contact with the lower half cylinder, has two opposing vernier scales engraved on it.", "The corresponding edge of the lower half is graduated in degrees, and read by the verniers to 2'.", "This half, which has a single pair of vertical sighting slits pierced in its surfaces, is mounted upon a tribrach provided with the usual three footscrews, and is fitted with a clamp and tangent screw for slow motion.", "The upper half cylinder can be rotated with respect to the lower half by a toothed wheel and pinion mechanism, actuated by a milled screw beneath the cylinder.", "The telescope is mounted so as to be always in the same vertical plane as the vernier zeros of the upper half cylinder.", "It has a fixed objective of 1-in. aperture and 7-in. focal length, and a rack-focussing eyepiece tube with a slide-focussing inverting eyepiece.", "The head of the tripod used with this instrument is also exhibited and illustrates the type usual in French construction.", "It is of wood, with brass slots for the feet of the tribrach, and is connected to the theodolite by a central plunger screw with opposing spring, which permits the small displacement of the instrument necessary for setting it horizontal."], "other": ["N/A", "Inv. 1919-415"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["Sch\u00e4tz\" or \"Estimation\" Microscope", "Nonien-Mikroskop", "Skalen-Mikroskop"], "makers": ["Hensoldt"], "organisations/institutions": ["Zeitschrift f\u00fcr Vermessungswesen", "Zeitschrift f\u00fcr Instrumentenkunde"], "dates": ["1870", "1902", "1912", "1879"], "places": ["Cassel"], "descriptions": ["represent three types of microscope for reading the circles of small theodolites.", "circles are completely enclosed in metal, dust-proof cases, and the microscopes are consequently provided with mirror reflecting tubes for illuminating the graduations.", "has a single fixed line marked in its focal plane, parallel to the graduations of the circle.", "used in theodolites having 10-cm. circles, graduated every 10'.", "position of the fixed microscope line between these graduations is estimated to a single minute.", "has a fixed vernier scale marked in its focal plane, and is used for theodolites having 13-cm. circles graduated to 5'.", "Ten divisions of the vernier scale correspond to nine of the circle, whence the position of the zero vernier line can be read to 30\", or even to 15\" by estimation.", "Alternate graduations of the vernier scale are numbered consecutively from 0 to 5, and represent minutes.", "is of the type devised by Hensoldt in 1870, and is used on theodolites having 13\u00b75-cm. circles, graduated in 20'.", "A fixed scale in the focal plane of the microscope has ten divisions, numbered right to left, exactly covering the interval between consecutive graduations of the circle.", "position of one circle graduation on this scale can be read to one-tenth of a scale division, i.e., to 12\".", "In this and the second microscope, the reading edges of the two scales slightly overlap each other, which ensures a sharper reading."], "other": ["Inv. 1914-553", "554", "555", "10-cm.", "10'", "13-cm.", "5'", "30\"", "15\"", "0", "5", "13\u00b75-cm.", "20'", "12\""]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": [], "makers": ["T. Cooke & Sons, Ltd."], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1921"], "places": ["York"], "descriptions": ["For setting up a surveying instrument on uneven ground, the tripod head is often provided with an arrangement permitting the instrument to be quickly levelled, without moving the legs of the tripod or the foot-screws, which last are only used in the final accurate levelling. Such a device is here exhibited. The trivet stage of the instrument is screwed to a central spherical section of a hollow ball, which fits sufficiently closely into a spherical socket fixed to the tripod legs to prevent any motion other than a rotation of the ball in the socket, permitting the top of the ball to be levelled irrespective of the top of the tripod socket. A circumferential clamp, provided with three thumb pieces, is threaded upon the outside of the socket, and serves to clamp the ball tightly within this when the instrument is approximately level, as shown by a small circular spirit level fixed in the top of the ball. A shank attached beneath the top plate of the ball marks its centre, and has a loop of cord attached for centring the instrument over the station point."], "other": ["Inv. 1921-561"]}
Unique_to_New: {"object_names": [], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": ["Science Museum Group"], "dates": [], "places": [], "descriptions": ["Tripod head allowing for quick levelling of surveying instruments on uneven ground.", "Features a ball-and-socket mechanism for rapid, approximate levelling, with final adjustment via foot-screws."], "other": ["A specific type of tripod head designed for surveying applications.", "This object is part of the Science Museum Group's collection."]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["SHIFTING CENTRE TRIPOD HEAD"], "makers": ["T. Cooke & Sons, Ltd."], "organisations/institutions": ["T. Cooke & Sons, Ltd."], "dates": ["1921"], "places": ["York"], "descriptions": ["This tripod head is fitted with a \"shifting centre\" arrangement, permitting the centre of the attached theodolite to be displaced any distance up to about 1 in. in any direction without removing the theodolite from the tripod or altering the position of this latter.", "This property is very useful in setting the theodolite accurately over the station point.", "The tripod head consists of five metal parts, namely a threaded plate to which the theodolite is screwed, a shoulder plate to which the tripod legs are attached, and three other parts which together form a collar, between the flanges of which the other two plates can be clamped.", "The outer diameter of the collar is 1\u00bd in., whilst the theodolite base plate and tripod shoulder plate have central apertures 2 in. and 2\u215b in. diam. respectively, so that either of them can be moved between the flanges independently, and clamped in the required relative position.", "A small circular spirit level is embedded in the top of the tripod plate and is used to set this approximately level.", "threaded plate to which the theodolite is screwed", "shoulder plate to which the tripod legs are attached", "collar", "small circular spirit level is embedded in the top of the tripod plate"], "other": ["Inv. 1921-539"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": [], "makers": ["Ordnance Survey (Donor)"], "organisations/institutions": ["Ordnance Survey", "Tower of London", "Ramsden's zenith sector"], "dates": ["1842 and 1850", "1852"], "places": ["Great Britain", "Ireland"], "descriptions": ["Used between 1842 and 1850", "On the destruction by fire at the Tower of London of Ramsden's zenith sector, which had previously been used to determine latitudes in the Principal Triangulation of Great Britain and Ireland, this sector was designed by Sir George Airy and constructed under his direction.", "It was used between 1842 and 1850 for determining the latitudes of twenty-seven stations of the Principal Triangulation.", "The telescope is pivoted horizontally to a revolving gunmetal frame which is itself pivoted vertically in a fixed cast-iron framework.", "The latter is supported upon a rectangular plate which in turn rests upon a cast-iron trough; this trough was usually screwed upon heavy wooden pickets driven into the ground.", "Four micrometer microscopes attached to the telescope serve to read its inclination to the zenith upon two graduated arcs, mounted upon the revolving frame.", "Each arc extends over 45\u00b0 of a circle of radius 20.5 in., and is divided to 5' and read by the microscopes to one-quarter of a second.", "The telescope has an objective of aperture 3.7 in. and 46 in. focal length, a micrometer diaphragm with five fixed and one movable wires, and an inverting eyepiece of magnification 70.", "Three sensitive spirit levels are fixed in adjustable bearings across the back of the revolving frame.", "In taking observations of a star's transit, the frame is quickly rotated to permit face east and face west readings of the telescope.", "The probable error of a single observation of latitude with this instrument was about 1\"."], "other": ["Inv. 1876-1202", "See \"Astronomical Observations made with Airy's Zenith Sector,\" Ordnance Survey, 1852."]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": [], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": ["Science Museum Group"], "dates": ["Beginning of the 19th century"], "places": ["America", "Copenhagen"], "descriptions": ["portable sector", "main telescope for observing stars near the zenith is pivoted horizontally near its objective end to the top of a vertical hollow brass cylinder, which carries at its lower end the fixed graduated sector over which the eyepiece of the telescope rotates", "Two micrometer microscopes fixed to the telescope serve to read its inclination to the vertical upon separate scales engraved on the sector", "scales, each of which covers about 15\u00b0 and is divided to 3', start at opposite ends of the sector and overlap about 5\u00b0 in the centre", "A third scale, continuous across the whole sector, is read by an index and serves as a check", "telescope has an objective of 2.5-in. aperture and 45-in. focal length", "Its motion over the sector is controlled by a clamp and tangent screw", "base of the vertical cylinder is connected to a horizontal circle by six vertical pillars and can rotate with this circle about a vertical axis coincident with the cylinder axis", "A long plummet suspended within the cylinder along its axis rests in a water vessel, inside the pillars, and serves to set the axis vertical. Its position is observed by two perpendicular microscopes fixed in the cylinder below the graduated sector", "A small telescope pivoted to the cylinder is used to observe circumpolar stars for setting the sector in the meridian", "horizontal circle has a diameter of 9 in. and is divided to 10\"", "vertical axis revolves inside a conical socket fixed to the tribrach, which carries three verniers for reading the circle to 10\"", "three levelling foot screws of the tribrach rest on the top plate of a strong mahogany tripod", "A small spirit level is mounted on the cylinder for rough levelling, and an adjustable counterpoise balances the telescope"], "other": ["Inv. 1891-24", "S.M. 1943", "Pearson's Astronomy, 1829, Vol. II, p. 546"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["zenith sector represented in these two photographs"], "makers": ["Troughton and Simms"], "organisations/institutions": ["Great Trigonometrical Survey of India"], "dates": ["1869", "1884-1900"], "places": ["India"], "descriptions": ["instrument was designed by Lt.-Col. A. Strange and constructed by Troughton and Simms in 1869 for use in the Great Trigonometrical Survey of India.", "By means of this and a somewhat improved instrument of similar design and make, many latitudes were determined in India during the period 1884-1900", "from 1890, however, a more convenient zenith telescope has been mostly employed in India for determining latitudes by Talcott's method.", "The instrument illustrated consists of a telescope of 4-in. aperture and 48-in. focal length, mounted rigidly upon a double sector which forms part of a graduated vertical circle of 3 ft. diam.", "The telescope can rotate upon a horizontal axis supported by a vertical metal pillar, and the vertical rotation is measured by means of four microscopes fixed to the frame carrying the axis.", "The instrument can be accurately adjusted upon its base frame so that the vertical sector revolves in the meridian plane, and its zero line is adjusted to be horizontal by means of a sensitive spirit level; the zero line is perpendicular to the telescope axis of sight, which therefore points to the zenith when the former is horizontal.", "The sector is graduated on silver every 5'; each limb extends over 55\u00b0 and is read by two microscopes, separated 20\" from each other, to single seconds; a separate smaller microscope serves to read degrees and minutes on the sector graduations.", "The telescope has a micrometer eyepiece fitted with a diagonal reflecting prism.", "A setting circle, of diameter 8 in., divided to 10' and read by vernier to 10\", is mounted on the telescope near its eyepiece, and is provided with a small level and also a very sensitive one, which latter permits the instrument to be used as a zenith telescope for observations by Talcott's method.", "The probable error of latitude determination with this instrument was about 0\u00b705\".", "See \"Great Trigonometrical Survey of India,\" Vol. XI, 1890."], "other": ["Prof. J. Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["plain mine surveyor's dial", "old circumferentor", "dial"], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": [], "places": ["England"], "descriptions": ["The plain mine surveyor's dial is very similar to the old circumferentor and has been much employed in England owing to its adaptability to surveying in low galleries and suitability for traversing.", "The instrument exhibited is a mid-19th-century dial, with a 5-in. compass ring graduated in degrees and a vernier fixed to the movable alidade reading to 3'.", "The compass ring and base are mounted upon an axial socket perpendicular to their planes and can be rotated about the central axis which fits in this socket and terminates in a spherical ball.", "This latter is gripped by another socket and can be clamped in any desired position so that the plane of the compass faces any direction.", "A slit in the socket allows the compass to take up a vertical position for measuring altitude angles.", "When measuring azimuth angles, the plane of the compass is levelled by means of a pair of perpendicular tube spirit levels fixed to the alidade.", "This is attached to the compass case, and carries combined back-sights and foresights at each end.", "The alidade and compass case, with the internal vernier scale, can be rotated independently of the compass ring and angles measured as in a theodolite, or the case can be clamped to the compass ring and the two rotated together about the axis of the latter for taking magnetic bearings, as in the ordinary compass.", "In the former case, the alidade is fitted with a tangent screw for slow-motion adjustment.", "The sights are 6 in. high and fixed at a distance of 1 ft. apart on the alidade.", "Each sight has both a slit and a pin-hole backsight and a long single-wire and a cross-wire foresight.", "The aperture and cross-wire sights are for use in measuring altitude angles.", "For this purpose the compass needle is locked by operating the lifting lever, the plane of the compass is set vertical, and the lid is placed in position on the box, and a plumb-line suspended from a stud in this lid.", "The opposite edge of the lid is graduated in degrees up to 45\u00b0 each way and has a scale of hypotenusal increments engraved on it."], "other": ["Inv. 1907-66."]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": [], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": [], "places": ["Cassel"], "descriptions": ["Theodolites with eccentrically mounted telescopes and vertical circles, which can be transited without requiring high standards projecting from the horizontal vernier plate, have been very generally employed by Continental mine surveyors owing to their suitability for work in low galleries. The example exhibited is of this type, the transit axis being mounted just above the vernier plate and carrying a telescope and vertical circle at one end, just clear of the horizontal circle."], "other": ["Inv. 1896-1197"]}
Unique_to_New: {"object_names": [], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": [], "places": [], "descriptions": ["A mining theodolite, also known as a transit instrument, is a surveying instrument used to measure both horizontal and vertical angles. This particular example was made by F.W. Breithaupt & Sohn. The design features an eccentrically mounted telescope and a vertical circle, allowing for transits without the need for high standards projecting from the horizontal vernier plate. This makes it particularly useful for surveying in low mine galleries, a common application for continental mine surveyors."], "other": ["SMG1935-284"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["Rand Model Mining Theodolite"], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": ["The Colliery Guardian"], "dates": ["July 27th, 1923"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["requirements of minor and routine mine surveying, particularly in collieries, can often be met by a dial of this type", "special feature of the dial exhibited is the sighting arrangement which is claimed to afford the advantages of open sights without the focussing difficulties of the latter", "compass box, mounted upon the tripod head by means of a ball and socket levelling arrangement, is designed for loose or fixed needle reading", "5-in. horizontal circle, graduated in degrees, numbered 0-360\u00b0 clockwise and read by opposing verniers to 1'", "needle circle also graduated in degrees, numbered 0-360\u00b0 in the anti-clockwise sense", "readings of the two circles thus correspond and may be checked by comparison", "horizontal circle is provided with a clamp and slow-motion screw", "compass box as a whole can be clamped to the base", "needle is 4\u00b725 in. long and is mounted freely upon a steel pivot; it is provided with a lifting and clamping arrangement, designed to prevent shocks", "Upon the rim of the compass box is pivoted a solid arm, carrying at its outer end the vertical circle with the sighting tube fixed thereto", "circle can rotate upon a horizontal axis in the arm, to which a vernier bracket is attached for reading the circle to 6'", "circle is of 3-in. diam., and is protected by a metal guard", "sighting tube is provided with a simple optical system of unit magnification, whereby the image of the target is brought into the same plane as the reference mark, which is a point or cross wires engraved on a glass diaphragm", "line of sight is above the centre of the compass box, and the supporting arm can be adjusted to enable vertical sights to be taken"], "other": ["Inv. 1925-3", "horizontal circle", "needle circle", "vertical circle", "sighting tube"]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["MINE MAGNETOMETER"], "makers": ["Cooke, Troughton & Simms, Ltd."], "organisations/institutions": ["Institute of Mining Surveyors", "Science Museum Group", "Trans."], "dates": ["1925"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["Many mining surveys, being based upon magnetic bearings, require an accurate determination of the magnetic meridian to serve as a periodical check and to connect them with the surface survey.", "The ordinary magnetic needle is not sufficiently sensitive to respond to the daily changes in the magnetic meridian, and the instrument exhibited was designed by Mr. T. Lindsay Galloway to enable the meridian to be fixed with the required accuracy.", "The instrument consists of a tribrach levelling stage, supporting a long cylindrical case within which is suspended an arrangement consisting of a plane mirror and a pendant connected by a fibre of unspun silk.", "Both mirror and pendant are mounted upon stems to which the ends of the fibre are fixed, and a small bar magnet is attached across the back of the mirror.", "Either the pendant stem or the mirror stem, or both together, can be clamped to the case by means of adjustable stirrup clamps, and the case can be inverted upon the tribrach levelling stage so that either the pendant or the mirror is uppermost.", "In using the instrument the case is first set up with the mirror above and the pendant below, and the latter is then unclamped and allowed to turn freely until it comes to rest, when it is clamped up again. By this means any twist is taken out of the fibre.", "The case is next inverted so that the mirror is below the pendant, whereupon it oscillates between two stops. If necessary, the case is rotated in azimuth to enable the mirror to come to rest with its plane in the magnetic meridian. If now a theodolite is directed on the mirror and adjusted until it centres the reflected image of a plummet suspended below its own axis, the line of sight will be perpendicular to the meridian.", "This type of magnetometer is now obsolete."], "other": ["T. Lindsay Galloway", "Vol. LVI, Part 4."]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": [], "makers": [], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1911-172"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["an instrument enabling an observer to keep himself at a fixed distance from another object, e.g., an observer in a boat from his ship, by keeping constant the angle which a known length on the distant object subtends at his position.", "In this type of station keeper, of which three examples are exhibited, a small glass prism of very small apex angle is mounted in a holder.", "The observer holds this at arm's length and views the distant fixed length partly through the prism and partly directly.", "If the direct sight of one extremity of the known length coincides with the image of the other extremity after refraction through the prism, his distance from the object must be invariable. The actual distance will depend upon the fixed length and the apex angle of the prism."], "other": []}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["box sextant"], "makers": ["Wharton"], "organisations/institutions": [], "dates": ["1911"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["This type of station keeper is essentially similar in construction to a box sextant, having a graduated arc of 6-in. radius extending over 20\u00b0.", "By measuring on this arc the angle subtended at his position by a fixed length on the distant object, the observer can calculate his distance from that object, or, having calculated the necessary angle, can set it on the instrument and keep his distance constant.", "The instrument consists of a sector-shaped box having its wider end open and its narrower end closed, save for a pin-hole aperture for sighting.", "At the open end, within the box, is mounted a fixed \"horizon\" mirror, whilst a movable index mirror is pivoted near the closed end and geared to an external rotating index arm, which moves over a graduated arc on the upper face of the box.", "The gearing is done by rack and pinion gear, which causes the index arm to rotate through twice the angle through which the index mirror moves.", "In using the instrument the observer sights one end of the distant base directly through the space below the horizon mirror, and the other end by double reflection at the two mirrors, and moves his position or the index arm until the two ends appear coincident."], "other": ["Inv. 1911-173", "5\u2032"]}

Nordenfelt", "for rangefinding at sea", "Observations are taken with the plane of the sextant vertical from a point on board ship at a known height above sea level upon the water line of a distant object and simultaneously upon the horizon.", "When the horizon and water line images are made to coincide by revolving the index arm, the reading of the index on the graduated arc gives the range of the distant object directly.", "The index mirror is not mounted upon the pivot of the rotating arm, but upon an eccentric pivot, connected to the arm by a cam and pin mechanism, which causes the mirror to rotate through a much smaller angle than the arm; this enables the angle swept out by the reflected ray to be varied very gradually between narrow limits, whilst the index traverses an arc of 60\u00b0 or thereabouts.", "As the angle of depression of the distant object below the horizon varies inversely as the range, if the base\u2014i.e. the height of the observer above sea level\u2014is constant, the arc of the sextant can be graduated to read the range directly.", "The effect of the dip of the horizon is allowed for on the graduated arcs."], "other": ["Presented by C. F. Casella & Co., Ltd.", "Inv. 1923-405"]}
Unique_to_New: {"object_names": ["Rangefinder type sextant"], "makers": ["C.F. Casella and Company, London", "Nordenfeldt, Thorsten Wilhelm"], "organisations/institutions": ["Science Museum Group"], "dates": ["1895-1905"], "places": ["Camden, London, England, United Kingdom"], "descriptions": ["Naval rangefinder designed by Thorsten Nordenfelt in 1884", "Anodized oval-pattern frame and anodized limb, wooden handle.", "Three exchangeable alloy scales, one is for an elevation of the eye of 96 feet, from 250-14,000 yards; one of for an elevation of the eye of 96 feet, from 250-20,000 yards; one if for an elevation of the eye of 47 feet, from 200-14,000 yards.", "No vernier, but two indicating lines; one is moved by a tangent screw, the other is rigid with the index arm.", "The tangent screw and clamping screw are on the back of the index arm.", "Index-glass adjustment by lever; adjustment of the horizon glass by screws.", "Threaded telescope bracket in two parts, fitted for correcting collimation error; perpendicular adjustment by rising-piece and a milled collar.", "Telescope (190 mm, large objective), erect image; telescope (124 mm, large objective, ocular missing), erect image.", "This instrument was patented by Thorsten Nordenfelt, no. 16,029 of 1884 (copy in the object file). Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": [], "makers": ["Carl Zeiss, Ltd.", "Dr. C. Pulfrich"], "organisations/institutions": ["Zeiss", "Revue g\u00e9n\u00e9rale des Sciences"], "dates": ["about 1901", "1914"], "places": [], "descriptions": ["special type of stereoscope", "designed by Dr. C. Pulfrich", "for measuring the relative displacement of corresponding points in the two views of an area surveyed from each end of a base, and deducing therefrom the position of the corresponding ground point with respect to the base.", "The position of each ground point is separately measured in terms of its azimuth, altitude and range (perpendicular to the base) from the left-hand base terminal point.", "The two negatives can be traversed together in a lateral direction parallel to their horizon lines by means of a rack operated by the wheel shown on the left of the instrument and known as the \"direction\" wheel, or the right-hand plate can be moved alone in the same direction by means of the wheel on the right-hand side of the instrument. The latter is known as the \"parallax\" or \"distance\" wheel.", "Each movement is registered by scales and verniers, whilst the \"distance\" wheel has a micrometer drum head for recording the smaller movements. The telescope can also be moved across the negative carriage in a direction parallel to the principal vertical lines of the views by means of the \"height\" wheel, shown in front of the middle part of the instrument, and the amount of motion measured on the \"height\" scale.", "The instrument is originally adjusted so that the mark appears to be at an infinite distance from the observer, in a direction coinciding with that of the principal point of the negatives, i.e. perpendicular to the base of the survey. When the mark is made to coincide with any point of the landscape, the readings of the direction, distance and height scales give the azimuth, range and altitude of that point with respect to the left base point.", "All the scales read to 0\u00b701 mm.", "The instrument is designed to take negatives of dimensions 12 cm. by 9 cm., such as are used in the photo-theodolite, by Zeiss"], "other": ["PHOTOGRAPH OF", "Lent by", "Inv.", "S.M."]}

Unique_to_Old: {"object_names": ["Thompson's stereo-plotter", "Pulfrich stereo-comparator", "plotting boards"], "makers": ["W. Watson & Sons, Ltd."], "organisations/institutions": ["School of Military Engineering", "Geographical Journal"], "dates": ["1907", "1908"], "places": ["R.E.", "camera station"], "descriptions": ["Photographs of Thompson's stereo-plotter", "Instrument for the purpose of automatically plotting the positions of points obtained by a stereo-photographic survey.", "Apparatus consists of a Pulfrich stereo-comparator, with a pair of plotting boards traversed by rulers connected to its measuring mechanism in such a manner that the co-ordinates of the point viewed in the comparator can be automatically plotted on the boards.", "In the Pulfrich comparator the three co-ordinates of any point surveyed, namely its direction, altitude and range, are measured by the motions of the main slide, the microscope bridge slide and the parallax slide respectively.", "The two plotting boards of the stereo-plotter, which may be called the plan and ele- vation boards respectively, are provided with one common \"ordinate\" ruler and separate \"abscissa\" rulers.", "The two latter are geared respectively to the main slide and microscope slide mechanism of the comparator, and are moved automatic- ally over their boards by the operation of setting the comparator on the view point."], "other": ["Vol. XXXI, 1908, pp. 534\u2013551"]}
